content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												This is NOT a game to play when you want to play games. It's a wandering game with the only purpose of wandering, observing and, in a small degree, interacting with the given world.Consists in a random generated world that passes through time, and time only. Day, dusk, night, dawn, spring to winter. You can interpret it the way you like, there is no story line, just that as life starts, it ends at some point. You can view as much energy in a winter landscape as on summer days, it is just your perspective in play. If you know the meaning of wanderlust, you get the idea.Now, do I recommend full price? Not quite, there has been no update since launch and there could be more content, but if it is on sale and you like the exploration-observation type of games, you bet.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2013
												When Proteus first came out, there was a lot of controversy over whether or not it counts as a game. Because if you don't think about it, there's nothing to do, no overarching story, no buttons to press, just one decently sized possibly alien island.I absolutely believe this counts as a game. More specifically, a child's game. This is how wee babes see the world: as something weird and beautiful that NEEDS to be explored. In Proteus, your entire goal is to do whatever. You interact with the world as a child does: by running at things and seeing what they do. This game will be a million times better once Oculus is made usable, and a million times more if we ever get haptic gloves out of them. The idea is total immersion into a brand new environment and learning how it exists. So no, it's not a classical game, but that is in no way a problem.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												I bought Proteus impulsively in the week it was released (I think) having read Rock Paper Shotgun's glowing review. Upon booting it up, I wandered around, peered at some trees and chased a rabbit, or perhaps a frog, before abandoning the game feeling miffed and shortchanged. I'm glad I came back.As I get older, I am increasingly finding that what I most want from a game is the ability to wander off and make my own fun. To explore, to pick flowers (probably Morrowind's doing), to fool around and to make my own choices. Or, given a choice, to reject it. I'm nothing if not contrary. Your interaction with Proteus' ever-changing world is subtle and, if impatient, as I was at first, you may miss what it has to offer. However, if you are willing to engage with it at its own relaxed pace then you will be rewarded with a beautiful, serene and wondrous experience, and one which is worth revisiting.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												This game is great. I bought it off of impulse when it was only $2.50, and I'm VERY glad I did.Unlike most modern day games, there is no other characters, no monsters, no leveling, no upgrades. The entire game is fully exploration-based. You have to find some stone circles, and they shift you from season to season, until you finish the game. Even though this game is a pixel-type game, the graphics and dynamics are amazing. The landscapes are everchanging, and beautiful. Clouds move in over the flatlands at night, the sun rises and sets, as does the moon. Heck, there are even shooting stars! The most unique element to this game is the music. Nobody will ever listen to the same music, ever. It all depends where you go. If you go near trees, you'll hear some additions to the music. If you go to a flower field, then you'll hear the music of the flowers. When you're walking through the landscape, it will all just blend together into a great, and truely unique musical score. If you are hesitant about getting this amazing game, don't be. You'll be very glad you did.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Okay, I was going to give this a negative review. I was. The first time I played the game, my emotions ranged from frustration to boredom. I didn't give this a negative review, and I'll tell you why, but let me get to the negative points you should absolutely know before you buy this:CONS:-The Pricetag: Not worth full price. Wait 'til it's at least half off, if not more. Seriously, people have put out better content (game-wise) for free.-Fiddle with the mouse a bit-- I found the sensitivity was way too low for my liking.-The keys to capture a postcard of the island and load an island don't work for me (probably something to do with my f9 through f11 keys having dual purpose). There is no option to change those keys.-You have to be in the mood to "experience" the game. If you're not relaxed, it's not worth it. Treat it like meditation rather than gaming. PROS:My second Proteus experience: I opened up the game today, fiddled with the mouse sensitivity, and dived right in. Today, my friends-- today, I was chill as ♥♥♥♥. I turned off the lights, put on some headphones, and just immersed myself in it. And it was like videogame Buddha walked right the ♥♥♥♥ over and whispered in my ear: "Yo. Yo, Carol-- this game right here is mother♥♥♥♥ing videogame nirvana." And it was glorious.TL;DR --If you like to meditate, but you have trouble doing it the old-fashioned way 'cuz you have, like, ADD or something (like me), or you end up falling asleep instead, THIS IS FOR YOU.   However, if you're looking for plot or goals or something other than walking around, don't get the game. Just don't.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Put simply, Proteus is lovely.  It's very simple, and it's not a very long game (one could find everything it has to offer so far in one or two sittings), but it is very attractive and soothing.There is no combat, no story, no progression in the strictest sense.  There is only exploration -- the game starts with the player out at sea just off a randomly-generated island.  The island itself is unpopulated, save for the local flora and fauna, but it is dotted with landmarks that must have been placed by people at some point (gravestones, towers, statues, etc.).  The origin of these objects is not the point, however.The only progression comes in the form of a vortex that appears at night, which will move the player forward through time, bringing them into the next season.  The appearance of the island changes from season to season, as do the resident fauna.  Each season seems to have its own strange occurrences as well.  (Here's a tip: don't enter the vortex on the first night of summer.  Stick around for the second day.)All in all, I highly recommend Proteus for anyone who enjoyed Flower or Journey, or just wants to take a break and enjoy chasing frogs, chickens, and fireflies around a colorful island for a little while.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												First thing, Proteus is not what I would conisder to be a game. There is no goal, no objective, and there really isn't anything to do. Well except be at utter peace with the world! Proteus is one of the greatest stress relievers I have ever known. It's always happy, and plays a relaxing soundtrack that changes depending on where you are. There are little monuments you can discover, so there is something to keep your mind occupied. The graphics are stylized to be like early 90's PC games. One thing that kept bothering me was the walking speed. I know its supposed to be peaceful, but I still felt like it was a bit slow. Proteus is everything I was hoping for, as I already have dozens of actual games.  Don't buy this because you want a game, buy it as a thing of art, and stress relief. EDIT: I recently just found out that this game does in fact have an ending, so there is an objective. However it took me only about 20 minutes to "finish" the game. But it was still pretty cool.Pros: +Stress relief+If you like exploring+Stylized graphics+Soundtrack+Secrets to findNeutral:*Movement speedNegitive:-Gameplay (its not really a game)Overall: 7/10 Buy only if its on sale, and only if you are interested in a game entirely made for relaxation.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2013
												In Greek Mythology, Proteus is a sea god who allegedly changes his shape to avoid fortelling the future - only those capable of "capturing" him have their fates revealed.I can say without a doubt that "Proteus" is the only game I've played that has forced me to experience the entire spectrum of emotion in under 45 minutes.It started with apprehensive curiosity, then uneasy comfort - the sensation of discovery and uncovering secrets. This shifted quickly to awe, wonder and a sense of all-encompassing, childlike joy as Spring turned to Summer. The euphoric happiness turned to a sense of nervousness, worry and despair as Fall set in. I don't think I can accurately explain the sense of dread, lonliness and fear I felt as I trudged through the snow and twisted trees of Winter. In a fog of confusion and turmoil I finally had a chance to look up to the heavens, one last time - and only then did I feel the peaceful silence of Death.+1, would recommend.

The artisans of Proteus somehow captured a place that I have  longed for, combining color palettes rarely seen, which stir such emotion.  What a masterful creation.  The genius in this artistic simplicity will be missed on many.  But for those whose minds can grasp the deeper significance and beauty, this game will excite you.  Thank you developers for putting so much love into this title.

												The one and only thing you do in this game is walk around. There are no goals, failstates, or challenges. This isn't necessarily why I don't recommend the game; I enjoyed the little time I got out of it. The game progresses through days and seasons on a timer, and it's very relaxing to explore the world. content:
Posted: April 10
												I'm gonna go ahead and hesitantly recommend Proteus. I'm not of the opinion that it's "not a game", although it could be argued. I just think the majority of people will only put the time into a single 40 minute playthrough, and it's hard to justify spending $10 on that.Proteus is absolutely beautiful though, one of the loveliest soundtracks and art styles of any game I've played. The sound effects are endearing too. In a lot of ways, Proteus is more of a musical adventure than anything. There's a fair few secrets to be discovered in its world. My complaints are as follows - It's very short.I could see people absolutely hating it for not having any clear objective or "not being a game".It crashed for me twice but only at launch. One time it launched but didn't have any sound until I restarted. Maybe I'm being a little too kind to Proteus because it's so charming and lovely to be a part of. I just really enjoyed my time in its randomly generated world. I recommend picking it up on sale if you're interested.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												This pushes the boundaries of what one would call gaming. It's more of a beautiful, semi random, synesthetic, exploration experience than anything else. That being said, if you like games or experiences different from the norm, that game is absolutely worth your time and money. I did two playthroughs back to back, and the experiences were significantly different each time. It's a strange feeling to not know when exactly you're finishing the game, and then feel a bit of sadness that this experience has to come to a close. This will definitely warrant more playthroughs for me.If mind altering substances of any sort are within your personal boundaries, I would highly recommend them paired with this game. Your experience and appreciation for this game will be greatly enhanced.

From this the game will tell you a story similar to a Robert Frost poem: Naturalistic, metaphorical, and most importantly: A plunge into the painful darkness of your own troubles unbeknownist to your own conscious frame of mind!Well perhaps the game doesn't act as a psychitrist, but it is an amazing piece of art to decypher for yourself!Fully approved for all artists.

Posted: February 8, 2013
												You wake up in an ocean... How did you get there ? No one knows... In the distance you see an island. You decide to swim towards it. Once you've arrived you see one of the most colorful environments you've ever seen. There are trees, flowers, lakes, bushes, the sun is shining; it just feels so good to be there. It... it feels right. You decide the explore the island a bit. The trees start making noises. Not the annoying or natural kind, but a relaxing kind. You walk on. As you walk on the flowers and bushes start making sounds as well. You realize it's a symphony, a symphony created for you. A few metres away you spot a group of creatures. You have no idea what sort of creature as it's one you've never ever seen before. You approach them, but... they get scared and run away. While running away, they start making sounds. It's a lovely sound. And even though there are scared you decide to follow them. After following them for a while, enjoying the sounds they create, you start to wander off again. You head into a different direction. The sun is setting and it's getting dark. Somehow, you're not scared. Even when it's dark the island still looks magical. There are fireflies and stars in the sky. There are even different animals now. You see some white spots that look like insects or flies, you're not sure. There's a whole swarm of them. Then you start to realize this 'swarm' is trying to draw your attention. Once again, you decide to follow them. Suddenly, these things start circling around you. More and more; it's sort of making you dizzy. You have no idea what's going on and your lose your sight for just a moment. Once you wake up again, you see that a lot of time has passed. Seasons have changed. Should you be afraid, or worried, you ask yourself. No, you tell yourself that it's fine. Because even though it looks like winter's approaching the island still looks magical.You decide to stay here,... forever.[Rating: 78/100]

												This game is only recommended for those that don't mind just wandering around a game landscape without any direction. Even then, for the asking price, $10 is steep. The pixel landscape is unique for this kind of thing, which adds some appeal to it, and there is something to do in the world at least, which is just pass by all the seasons. content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												This game is amazingly beautiful, a cross between Minecraft and Journey that takes the best of each game's beauty and adventure. Although this game has no goal, it offers a unique free-roam adventure that lets you go where you want and experience the mystery and views of each randomly generated island. One of it's best qualities is the music; the adaptive audio (which Ed Key and David Kanaga have mastered) makes the game just that much better, and other than the music, the sound effects are great in their own way. I think that this game is one of the most relaxing and calm games i've ever played and never fails to give me a great time. I would definitly recommend this game for anyone who enjoyed the games mentioned above.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2013
												I'm not sure this counts as a game, but it definitely is a piece of art.The screenshots capture the mood of the game very well, you begin near an island which you head towards, then move across the island listening to dynamic 'music' as you approach trees, flowers, towers, stone circles and mountains. Each of these elements change slowly over time. Once night falls, you find a stone circle that will advance time to the next season. Once you have experienced Spring, Summer, Autumn and Winter you will rise above the island and your experience will be over.The islands are randomly generated, so each experience is slightly different.Whilst I don't think this counts as a game, it is a beautiful and striking piece of art. It is slow and peaceful, something that takes time and patience, but there is something to appreciate here. Climbing a mountain above the morning mist in summer and watching the clouds roll below you is really quite moving, the stars spin away slowly at night and you can see comets streaking the sky on occassion. Small clusters of chickens run from you, conjuring up another layer of the dynamic music. Part of the charm of the game is moving near these small elements and seeing how they react, what they do, if anything at all. Sometimes just sitting and watching these elements reveals small surprises.The graphics are simplistic, but there is a strength in their simplicity. The style brings to mind old text adventure game screens brought to life. The colour pallette is really striking and part of the strength of the games beauty. The sun sets and you see the sky and the clouds and the trees change from greens to browns to oranges, into the cool blues of night.A walk through a virtual environment that may not be for everyone, but for those patient and willing to try, it is an experience unlike anything else.

content:

												I played this 0.2 hours longer than I should have. While I consider myself quite open-minded about games and actually dislike the kind of prescriptive experience we sometimes get in AAA titles, this 'game' takes minimalism to a new level. No doubt someone out there views this as art, given how subjective our tastes can be. For me, I feel as if my life could be better spent staring out the window at the row of terraced houses across the street.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												Proteus is not a game, it's an experience. Frankly, I think it could've been more. If you've ever played Dear Esther before, (yes, I  own it) you know it wasn't much of a game, just a "showcase" of how powerful it's engine was. Proteus is the same in many ways, but its a pixel-y game, showcasing what the developers can do.I assume this is open world. The only reason I'm still attempting to play it is because of the music, but I'll get that later. It may just be an island, but you can walk around wherever you want and "do" whatever you want. You can't click on anything, you can just walk around, "enjoy" the art style, and enjoy (I say in a positive way) the music. There is no point to Proteus. The only main objective  is to drift away in the music, and I'd glaadly just open the game for the music. The soundtrack is pretty much the only thing it has going for it. Don't get me wrong, I kind of like the colorful, pixel world, but what really sold me was in fact the soundtrack.If you can find the soundtrack to this "game", just get that. To be honest, I don't think that Proteus is worth it's price tag.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Proteus is nowhere near worth the current $9.99 price tag. I'll start by saying that much. That said, this is one of the most "casual" gaming experiences you will ever play. There is no purpose to Proteus other than to provide the player with a unique world to explore along with a relaxing soundtrack. You can not interact with any objects. You can not jump. All you can do is keep exploring the repetitive yet distinctively unique world. There is no narrative behind Proteus so nothing drives it forward and that is what this game lacks the most, some kind of goal. There are games which take a simple approach and execute so fluently and perfectly such as Journey or Minecraft. There is nothing to achieve out of this game and after some time, the soothing soundtrack and lush world gets old and then the game justs gets boring. And It gets boring fast. 5/10

												This is a good game. There is no doubt about that. However, I do not want to play it as I much as I did, Journey. Proteus, is great, there are parts I love. One of the main things I love, is the interaction with the animals  and dependent on the experince of playing, how hard it will hurt to close the eyes and end the game. However, in comprasion to Journey, there is no contest. Joureny will intrigue you, isolate you, surpise you and it will then destroy you. Proteus, will intrigue you, isolate you, surpise you. However it will not destroy you. It is not as emontianlly griping, this it's flaw. Nevertheless I like it, and you should buy it. It is a great game, it is worth it. Just play Journey after it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												Proteus is a game I am particularly fond of myself, you play as a shipwrecked pirate captain, who finds himself lost in an island where nobody wants to be his friend. The moment you set foot on the island, you seal your fate. You make your best attempts at befriending the local population, but your wooden peg and eyepatch give it away, nobody wants to be a pirate's friend. You will traverse the scenery of this barren land, only to find an ancient spell that was cast on it many seasons past. Will mastering the ancient spell cast on the island allow you to befriend the local population and maybe recover your eye and leg, or are those sacrifices long past behind you?

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												I have no idea how to review this to be honest. I've had it for a while and decided I'd get other games that fall within the "Art" genre. Proteus functions I suppose. It's pretty I can say that. It can be relaxing to go to after a bad day. I guess the problem I have is what am I supposed to feel in this game? I've tried other games such as Dear Esther, Stanley Parable and Thirty Flights Of Lovin but they all had a story in some degree. What would you like me to say? That it's good? I can't say that. That it's bad? No that would imply there is something wrong with it. So I'll leave you with this: Don't expect anything at all with this game. Think of nothing prior to it. Make your own assumptions of what it is. If you like it then thats great but if you don't like it then don't say that it is a half made game. This is what the game developers were hoping to achieve.Because I have to I give it 5/10 It exists. Try it out if you like the idea, unlike me who has no idea what to think of it.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												#####1.5 hours playtime as of release of review##### Overview Proteus is an instantly appealing and fun little casual indie game. You wander around an island with no idea what you are suppose to be doing. You will encounter some cute little creatures and listen in awe as the charming sound immerses you in the ethereal world. Proteus is a fairly short, but highly replayable game. Components Visuals - The visuals of Proteus are very simplistic and stylized, but very pretty. This game may not have the fanciest graphics, yet the unique charm is captivating and pleasing to the eye. The game features a day/night cycle and even the four different seasons! This game's ethereal landscape is a place I could lose myself in for ages. Overall, Proteus has some incredible visuals.Audio - The audio is one of the most major components of Proteus. If you lack a good quality audio device, you won't enjoy this game nearly as much. Every action you make is rewarded with beautiful sounds, and as cute creatures scuttle away, beautiful melodies are formed. The music adapts to the season and time of day, and it always sounds serene and tranquil. Overall, the audio quality of Proteus is phenomenal. Gameplay - The gameplay of Proteus is very simple. You are dropped into an ocean as soon as you start and you make your way towards a procedually generated island. The only thing you'll be doing on this island is walking, and exploring. It may sound boring, but there is so much to see and discover that it remains fun. However, I did find the gameplay to be fairly shallow.Story - N/aFunctionality - Proteus is a very simplistic game. It will perform well even on weaker systems. This is a technically well performing game which is bug-free. Pros  Very memorable Beautiful, ethereal landscape So much too see and discover that you will need to play it at least twice Phenominal audio design Cons  Minimal interaction Minimal gameplay Relatively short Heftily priced  Conclusion If you're looking for a gorgeous casual exploration game, then I highly suggest Proteus.In conclusion, I suggest getting this game for the incredible and unique experience, but it's only worth it if you're getting this while it's on sale.I give this game a 5.5/10, it was a memorable and fantastical experience, but feels shallow and short.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												Proteus is a game I am particularly fond of myself, you play as a shipwrecked pirate captain, who finds himself lost in an island where nobody wants to be his friend. The moment you set foot on the island, you seal your fate. You make your best attempts at befriending the local population, but your wooden peg and eyepatch give it away, nobody wants to be a pirate's friend. You will traverse the scenery of this barren land, only to find an ancient spell that was cast on it many seasons past. Will mastering the ancient spell cast on the island allow you to befriend the local population and maybe recover your eye and leg, or are those sacrifices long past behind you?

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												This is interesting from an artistic perspective. When you view the screenshots, it may not look like much with its extremely dated pixelated graphics, but the developers sure knew how to use that visual style in interesting ways. The music is generated by the changing landscape as you explore and those willing to appreciate this "game" as artistic expression will probably enjoy that immensely. The colors are great, the sprite effects visually interesting. Proteus is a wonderful world to explore for about 20 minutes. Then you realize there's no point to it and the experience is over. It's like stopping to look at a painting in a museum, taking it in, and moving on. There is no "game" here in any traditional sense. It's just exploration and soothing music. What you see in the trailer is the highlights of what you'll see in-game. If Proteus were $1 or 2, I would probably recommend it. At $10, I cannot. Just check out a "Let's Play" on YouTube. Everything you can get out of "playing" this game, can be achieved watching a YouTube video, or a bunch of official trailers.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2013
												Have you ever heard the fable about the Emperor's New Clothes? It's the story of an Emperor who starts walking around outside in the nude and everyone around him has nothing but praise for his "new clothes". Basically each bystander knows that he's actually naked but they're too afraid of going against the crowd by acknowledging it publicly. That story is just like this game. All the reviewers I've seen say that it's "intoxicating" They say it's so good that it'll just suck the hours away with its immersive genius. I say this "game" is in fact a cynical practical joke made by the developer at the gaming community's expense with the explicit purpose of proving that people will buy *anything*. There is no interactivity whatsoever. The game consists of pixels of alternating colors (sometimes they move and sometimes they don't) accompanied by stereotypically surreal ambient music. I do get (and even appreciate) that sometimes developers push the boundaries of what a game actually is (Osmos, etc.) but under no circumstances... on no planet... could this title honestly be referred to as a "game". My experience consisted of walking around aimlessly for about 10 minutes until I realized that you can't do anything. Literally. A youtube video is more interactive than this (since you can at least pause it). I bought this game based on having read several reviews but now I seriously regret it. I want my $10 back. Selling this title on Steam without appropriate warnings, prominently placed, is tantamount to theft.Update (01/13/14) -Below is a snippet from a user review on metacritic that says it way better than I did:"Proteus isn't actually a video game, it isn't even an interactive movie. I'd hardly even call it an "experience" let alone the digital Nirvana people claim it is. Proteus takes the "player" to an island which is supposedly randomly generated and it features a lot of pixelated objects passing for natural objects and animals. The player walks around using the WASD keys (W, mostly) and looks around with the mouse the music changes according to where you are walking and what you are looking at. Although the music will speak to New-Age electronic fans the game play won't. Neither will the graphics. Animals scurrying away and solid objects blocking your path is about the extent of your interaction with the world. There is supposedly an end to the game and I believe that "progress" is made by chasing certain objects in the world. This game is simply put an over-priced art-house project that one would expect to find on as a sort of attachment to a game developer's résumé. The odd thing is the high praise the game receives."

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												It's a walk through an art piece. It's a game in which you explore and interact with the world. What I didn't like about it was the fact that the only way to *interact* with the world was to *look* at it and *be* in it. I wish the game would provide some way to establish goals or at least give the "player" a little bit more to intrigue them. It doesn't ever tell you why you appeared suddenly in the ocean near an island and must now wander aimlessly. You don't need to eat, or sleep, apparently. Overall it's quite zen, though. Walking around and hearing the music reflect your environment is actually a very strong aspect of the game. And even though I felt a burning desire to figure out what the game had to offer, eventually it sort of washed itself away and I felt content with being in the world.As far as a recommendation, it's quite a good experience, but it's one of those games that questions what a game is. Being so abstract and artistic, I don't think it'll be accessible to most audiences.To summarize my recommendation: I like it, but a lot of people won't. I recommend you play it. But don't expect to *do* much in the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Proteus isn't really a "game" exactly, but that doesn't mean it isn't enjoyable. The gameplay is restricted to walking around, exploring a randomly generated island, being guided by your own instict and nothing more.While a lot of people would hate this game because it has no interactivity and no real gameplay, don't knock it until you try it. Proteus isn't for those that would rather relax by playing something intense. Instead, Proteus is for those that come in after a long stressful day and want to relax by winding down.The music and sounds can really capture the senses, if you'll let them. Plus, the various things you find can catch your attention and give you a new direction to explore in. If you want something to help you get away from a bad day, give Proteus a try. It's not that expensive and every island is different, so it's worth a try. Just don't expect to kill anything or talk to anyone.

												First thing you need to know about Proteus is that it is not a "game" in the classic sense of the word.It doesn't contain much interaction or any tasks to complete whatsoever, so if this what you are looking for this title may simply not be for you.What it does offer is an interesting audio-visual experience with the freedom to explore procedurally generated islands made of  stylised 8bit 2D/3D hybrid visuals. It would be right to say that there is simply not much to Proteus, but that is the point of it. It is not meant to provide high octane action or hours of convoluted plot. It simply places you in its world in order to for you to see the sights (with some neat stuff happening at night) and enjoy a relaxing moment. It could best be compared as a pleasant, waking dream.It will not appeal to everyone, but those interested in being sent to a surealist dreamscape for a few dozen minutes may just find something to enjoy.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Video games teach us to follow linear pathways to achieve a clear objective and reach a single, desirable end, a clear "game over" where we know we've succeeded or failed. Proteus could not deviate from that system farther. The first time I opened the game (which was just now), I found myself tearing up over... well, it's beauty, it's adventure, it's hard to describe. It's Proteus. (now admittedly I'm a huge wimp, but the experience was really emotionally moving, and not at all something I expected from a video game :P) It felt like five minutes of gametime; my Steam says I've logged five times that much. If any game is truly magical, it's Proteus.Most games are easily beatable with a lot of grinding and the help of a google search, a wiki, or a friend, but the thing about Proteus is you don't "beat" it. You just play it. That's somewhat of a radical thing in video games, I think, and it makes playing Proteus a real stress-relieving experience. There's nothing to tell you what's going to happen, or even how you go about making it happen - that's what playing the game is for! You explore, you learn, you discover. It's a game that doesn't bend itself to the will of a dedicated, competitive player, it's a game that takes you along for an adventure. The music has the quality of pre-composed pieces but is formed naturally as you explore the environment, which changes with what seems to be a mind of its own. Swim to that island. Bump into that rock. Follow that blue hopping thing. Who knows where you'll end up? I don't. My mom don't. The wiki don't. At least I sure hope it don't... This game is whatever you want it to be, so I encourage any players not to start with asking what they can find or how to find it, but just to hop into the game and enter their own little dreamscape where anything and everything can happen. :3On the practical side the game is very friendly with the options. You can play it fullscreen or in a window and you can adjust your field-of-view and mouse sensitivity very easily and even do it ingame if you please. The creators have pulled out all the stops to make sure this game is a convenient and comfortable experience as well as a beautiful one. I reckon I'd pay the full ten bucks for it, but if you can, get it on sale; whenever you can get your hands on it, Proteus will be waiting for you. :PThe game's not for everyone, but if you enjoy video games as an art form, if you're looking for a truly unique adventure that's both dynamic and peaceful at the same time, and heck, if you just flippin want to, give Proteus a try. This is a world I wouldn't mind going to when I die.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Proteus,A Game of exploration, sound, sight, peace.When i first got this game, i was looking at it for the art. See, I am a big fan of videogames with art. When i downloaded and launched proteus, little did i know what was going to hit me.First Impression:When I awoke on the island, the first thing i noticed was the art (suprising, huh?). The art is almost an old school style atari-like style. This pleased me, for i was sick of games such as Call of Duty and other major FPS games. They try to competet to have the most realistic graphics. This game completely throws it away and gives you beutiful colors.Gameplay:Proteus is a game with no goal. You dont try to blow up the other ships, nor try to get the best KDR ratio to brag with your friends. This is a game about sight and sound. What you look at and where you are changes the soundtrack very uniquely. For example, there was a line of tree stumps. as each one of them got out of my sight they would play a deep bass note. There are also animals on the island. For example, some bees may be chilling by a treee enjoying proteus with you, but when you come close they al gather together. When they do this, they will chase you (but not hurt you) and you will get a speed boost. And yep, soundtrack altered with bees. Nature will sometimes act of of the ordinary, such as youll see a bunch of leaves flying into a kind of circel in the middle of the night. As you approach, time speeds up with multiple days fly by. Then, your screen goes bright white. When the whitness fades.... buy the game to find out :).Final Note Before Pros/Cons:This game gave me a huge amount of peace/zen. Its almost liek meditating in an awesome way. It calms down your heart and your mind making you focus on everything around you. For example the day i got this game, i had goten a test back... the grade i got made me feel terrible. I dont do bad at school, but this grade was below my average. I come home feeling like crap and all, and boot up my computer. First thing i go to is proteus. I had just goten it and i wanted to check it out to see how it works and all. After onoy 15 minutes of gameplay, i was relaxed and ready to finish off my day.Pros:Artwork is different and fun.No goal makes you wander and explore.Intresting soundtrack that interacts with you.Cools you down and makes you peaceful.No guys decked in military uniforms trying to headshot there way to a better KDR.Cons (partially biased):No goal making it unapealing to some (although i do like this because it gives me a sense of freedom)Walking speed is fairly slow (probably because its a slow paced game)Mouse/Trackpad is not very sensitive (though it adds up to a nice way to look around)Mouse/Trackpad keeps some motion even when you stop. (doesnt affect game too much and it eventually stops, but sometimes annoying)OVERALL:8/10Great game to play in your spare time.P.S.I hope you found my review helpful and honest! Any questions? Just add me!-Dagz :3(right now its only at 2 dollars, so if you read this within the next 20 hours id recomend buyin git cheap at 80% off :D)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												In Proteus you awake, walking on the water for some reason, on a randomly generated "garden of eden like island. Now there is not really any interaction within this game, if you can call it a game (Its sorta more like art). Proteus is all about immersing yourself in the ambient environment around you. As you explore the island you will find that the music of the game is influenced by your actions. whether you decide to follow a frog, the hoot of an owl, or even listen to the wind weave through the leaves. During the night if you follow the falling.. uhh stars, (I think that's what they are anyway) will lead you to a sort of worm hole that changes the season from spring, summer, fall , and winter. Proteus really exploits your curiosity, and curious is really how you feel while playing Proteus. Eventually You will find strange things scattered over the island, like grave stones, broken towers, cottages, and the very mysterious circle of totems. Now this game really doesn't appeal to everyone, I would recommend it if you like to relax while playing video games and have patience to explore the beautiful world of proteus. Because the world truly is beautiful. However the price of $10 seems a bit much for this game, as there are some better games on steam for cheaper. But I still recommend it, that is if you are interested in this type of game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
												Not really recommended, but it was interesting and short. You're on a minimalist island that's a little... too minimalist? The game tries to strike a balance between peaceful wandering and curious exploration, but there's too many hills over which there's just more hills, and too many animals or plants that just sit there or plainly run away.  Finding a pretty or intriguing event feels quite special, but was it really worth the minutes of walking past even more samey trees and slopes?I like my Dear Esters and my Gone Homes etc, but this felt too sparse. It has a lovely ending (I hit it an hour in) that leaves a good taste in the mouth, which I expect is where a lot of the positive reviews come from. Looking online, there doesn't seem to be much I missed, and I'm left wondering what all the fuss was about, for something that was maybe 1-2 steps above a quick, touching browser game.

It really has some beautiful scenery, but it's not enough.I have no idea how the hell did this "something" ended up on Steam. If you want to expand your library with something you won't "play" for more than 3 minutes, go ahead and buy Proteus and enjoy this... don't know how to call it, but it's definitely not a game.I'm really sad to see that a lots of cool Greenlight games are rejected and not founded, but this awful something in the disguise of "artistic, relaxing game" is in Steam catalog for 7 eurs...

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Literally all you do in this game is walk around a world and look at it. This might be a cool concept if the game didn't look like it was made on a calculator. Now I'm NEVER someone to say a game is bad just because of the graphics, but when a game's primary focus is its visuals, exploration, and all that, it NEEDS to be at least remotely pleasing to the eye, which this game is not. Don't let the trailer fool you like it did for me. This is not some quirky game where the worlds are full of fun mysteries and wonders to unravel. You walk around a boring world that you can't do anything in and where nothing is interesting. You're basically spending $10 to have your eyes♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and your sense of boredom sent to a new peak.

number of helpful: 10 of 21 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												For the first few minutes I was kind of impressed.  The island was bigger than I had imagined based on my initial sighting.  I started to look around and some things in the distance caught my eye.  I found a cabin I couldn't enter.  Some animals that I could sort of chase.  And a weird circle of statues on a mountain that made the stars pulse like the universe was having a seizure.  And then I thought, "Ok, so I've been here 5-10 minutes... I've seen most of what I can pick out as interesting features... is this it?"  I walked around a bit more thinking, "What do I do now?  Are there any goals or things to look for if only I had some hints?'"  This is when I decided there was nothing more to do and quit the game.And then I remembered the game was put out on PS3/Vita where it was required to have trophies.  And as I looked at the Proteus trophy list (here: http://www.playstationtrophies.org/game/proteus/trophies/ ), I once again felt like I got the short end of the stick by supporting this developer on PC before they ported their game to consoles and left us forgotten (much like those jerks at KLEI).  Looking through the trophy guide there, at quick glance, it seems like the developer actually put some thought and effort into the trophy list, so I searched through the community forums here on Steam to see if anything was mentioned as far as developer commentary on the possibility of an achievement patch or why there will be none.  Even KLEI, for all their hypocritical behaviour, at least tried to come up with a reason for not porting the trophies for Don't Starve into Steam achievements... but there was nothing.  Even google didn't turn up much.  Perusing the article on the game over at wikipedia, I found that the dev said that the features added to the PS versions "could come to PC in the future".  This was over a year ago and nothing has been seen regarding it since then... and it's an absolute shame.  Looking at the guides in the community section, it seems there's an actual goal and some other neat aspects of the game that casual gamers and players not using guides will miss out on.  Achievements would be a way to help clue people in on theses aspects and encourage them with hints on ways to find them... but Steam users are left wanting and envious of the console ports.I wish more developers would support their PC games and update them with the added content seen when the games are ported to consoles, much like The Astronauts have just done with The Vanishing of Ethan Carter (and the achievements added will probably match the PS4 trophy list, if I had to guess).Don't buy this game, put your money toward something like The Vanishing of Ethan Carter instead.

												This game i peacefull, full of colours, strange sounds and pixels. An everyone's favorite combination! All you do is to walk around, and explore. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Proteus is a joy to experience. Contrary to some folk, I always find new things to do each time I take a wander - it is up to you what you do and where you go. Sometimes I just like to watch a sunset, stare at the sun or stars, or watch the clouds roll by in the lowlands. Other times, I go chasing chickens and see where I can get them to. When it is dark, I go and try to find owls. In all honesty, I find Proteus to be an intense experience (in a good way) in which I have to turn down the lights, put the headphones on and minimize all other distractions. Go explore! There is plenty to do.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												I can not emfasize how much I hat this game. It is hard to determin were to start picking this game apart. So, let's start with the excessive violence. The game begins with blaring 80's pop synth, and thrusts you into an environment that impedes progresion unless you violently murder everything in your path. It made me sick to even look at the screen. Most of the screen was covered in red, and when it wasn't, I was acosted by scenes of brutal gore. Moving on to the other primary offensive factor! The story is just aful, having no interesting charaters or any sign of a coherent narrative. The story killed my ability to tink, causing the variety of spelling erors in this revu. All in al, 4/5 trucks and trains. Wood replay.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
Product received for free
												There will come soft rains and the smell of the ground,And swallows circling with their shimmering sound;And frogs in the pools, singing at night,And wild plum trees in tremulous white,Robins will wear their feathery fire,Whistling their whims on a low fence-wire;And not one will know of the war, not oneWill care at last when it is done.Not one would mind, neither bird nor tree,If mankind perished utterly;And Spring herself, when she woke at dawn,Would scarcely know that we were gone.-Sara TeasdaleThis was a very good experience. I rushed through it, though. You play as someone who stumbles upon an island, and as you progress through the year, you get a lot of different emotions. I don't want to spoil it, but it had some moments that felt tense, mostly due to the calming nature of the rest of the game. I chose the poem because the game reminded me of a movie adaptation of it, and I seriously felt like the last man (or woman) on earth, up until the end. I recommend this if you have a "musical personality"

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I recommend this game to everyone. This is an amazing example of in-game immersion without having to care about a story line, or a certain set of characters...*looking at you "Beyond Two Souls"* But I digress, all of my friends should take advantage of this sale. Proteus has a certain atmosphere most games aren't able to master. Its using the persons mind to imagine what the world "feels" like. Unlike most Triple A games where HD graphics are the norm, Proteus takes gaming back to when you had to IMAGINE what was happening on screen and believe you were in it. Its a certain charm most games lose due to the game screaming at you to go to the next checkpoint, or mission when they really could focus on the environment and setting. Thats why I play FPS's like CoD and heavily critize the campaign for its lack there of immersion. All around this game is not a game, its a statement about modern gaming. I find it to be pretty true and agree with it. :)

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												I thought I had seen everything this game had to offer within the first five minutes. I'm now very glad I didn't quit at that point. This game had so many cool and unexpected things that happened in it! It was absolutely beautiful. The music, the scenery, the atmosphere in general. By the time I beat the game, when everything was wrapping to a slow serene peaceful close, I got the shivers big time. This game may not be a standard video game, but I'd say give it a play all the way through. You'll know when you've finished. Not having any direction at all, and being dropped into this mysterious and beautiful world was quite entertaining. Figuring things out was very rewarding. This game is a work of art. It also serves as a feel good meditation-like experience. It really is something. Give it a shot!

content:
Posted: February 1, 2013
												Proteus isn't a game.  I'd compare it to Dear Esther but Dear Esther actually had a linear path, story, and ending.  Proteus is just a visual and auditory pleasure.  As the description says, the audio changes as you traverse, not just around the island but when you bump into other oddities that add to the curiousty that is Proteus.  I was going to be quick to dismiss it as a "Fun for a few minutes but that's it" sort of thing but then I ran across a few locations that intrigued me.  There are certain places and objects  that cause subtle change, as long as you're patient enough to look for it.  It's these little tiny and hidden details that delight me to keep exploring.I'd definitely call this one a "Come back from time to time" type of experience, when feeling a desire to just wander and think, without being burdened by anything else.I honestly can't give this a rating.  It's good but for completely different reasons than the ones I'm used to.

Not having any direction at all, and being dropped into this mysterious and beautiful world was quite entertaining. Figuring things out was very rewarding. This game is a work of art. It also serves as a feel good meditation-like experience. It really is something. Give it a shot!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												SUMMARY: A relaxing game where you wander around a procedurally generated island, and your travels create the soundtrack.  With some interesting visuals and a focus on playing around, the game is for people who want something experimental and playful and/or want to back an innovative game.  Not for something where you're looking for scores, skilltrees, and so on.Proteus is wandering through a child's drawing while listening to a freeform prog rock soundtrack.  If that appeals to you, then it's probably a game to get.  Be warned - it's not for everyone.Every time you start Proteus, you end up in the ocean near a procedurally generated island.  As you explore, the sound reflects the surroundings.  You wander into the soundtrack, as it were.Exploring the island allows you to experience various sites, find interesting things, or just hang out.  There's various landmarks in each game that provide certain features, as well as plenty of randomness.  There's some discoveries to be made that will let you experience the game in depth, and there is an "end" to get to if you want (and lets you experience assorted visual and auditory experiences).Then?  You can start again.It's really a game of wandering, playing on that urge that often drives us to see "just what's around here", combined with the freeform soundtrack.  It's compelling and relaxing, like you're experiencing a dream.If you want a game with skilltrees, combat, construction, etc. it isn't for you.  You don't do anything except choose where you go and what you experience.  I find myself playing it when I need to take a short break, and it's surprisingly soothing.Is it for you?  Like many games it depends on you - if the description has you interested, it probably is.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2013
												It is... kind of a weird game. In fact, it is not exactly a game, more like an exploration sort of thing. It seems to be more a kind of demo to render the island, which is randomly generated every time.When you visit the stone circle at night, you'll see a whirling circle of orbs. If you step in its ring, you'll skip to the next season. Starting at spring, you ultimately end up in winter. It is kind of interesting to see the various seasons. But as the game resolution is so low (or rather, very pixelated), it is not exactly something to linger too long at.There are some landmarks on every generated island which are interesting to find and wonder about, but that's basically all you can do with those landmarks. You can't interact with those at all.I'd not suggest to buy this game unless it was part of some indie bundle anyway (which was how I got this). Mostly because 1) it is not exactly a game and 2) there is not terribly much to do besides just wandering around and looking at the differences in scenery per season.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Ah, I hate to put a "no" review for Proteus. It's a quirky little game that has some heart to it.Proteus is one of those 'experience' games a-la Journey where the enjoyment is in experiencing what is around you. For what it's worth, Proteus does offer a lot of charm; the background melodies combine with the various sounds of your island to create a hypnotic symphony. The wide open environment reminds a lot of Minecraft, only in a beautiful cell-shaded manner.But unlike Minecraft or Journey, Proteus lacks any form of gameplay. It consists of wandering around until you find something that piques your curiosity, investigating it, and then leaving. And there are a couple non-standard things to find in Proteus; if a player feels like they're being led somewhere, there's probably something to find. Alas, there could stand to be way more of these curiosities, as they are too few. Exploration is all that Proteus has, yet Minecraft does it with wider worlds, more mysteries, more gameplay, and the ability to express one's own artsy fartsy tendencies rather than just experiencing those of another.If you got the game as part of a bundle, it may be worth it to play; the experience is very serene, and the way the music synergizes with the environment is wonderful. However, even though the game may be "art," it is missing an actual game, and I would not recommend its actual purchase.Final verdict:Exploration games are an excellent concept, but it needed way more to be as memorable as something like Journey.On a scale out of 10 where 4.7 is considered "average," this game would rank at a 3.5 - has potential, but doesn't necessarily meet it.

												Not a game, and not much to it. There are no mechanics to speak of. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Definitely not a game for everybody.  Certainly not for me.  After forcing myself to endure a few minutes of play, I just can't understand the appeal.  I guess I'm just not into the "artistic expression" this game tries to convey.  Maybe if there were goals of some kind, I could get into it.You start off in the water and then wander around a 3d-ish island.  Music changes now and again.  Animal-like things bounce around, rain falls, touching certain stones does something weird I'm not even entirely sure of.  It's pretty much an exploration game with no long-term state and no goals.  For some, this may be appealing, but for me it was just not terribly interesting.I could recommend it to people if its base price were more in the $3 range.  But $10?  I can't really see recommending it to anybody for that price, even if this style were up their alley.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This is a game where you slowly walk around while soothing electronic noises sedate you.  If that sounds interesting to you, you should try it.Proteus has garnered a lot of praise as an art game, but the "art game" genre is so young that virtually every entry in it is guaranteed decent reviews.  Personally, I suspect that this is because game reviewers, who are more accustomed to reviewing the sort of conventional pulp titles that built the industry, are afraid that giving a negative review to a game like Proteus might make them look stupid.But honestly, this game isn't some kind of artistic masterpiece on any level.  The player slowly walks around in a simplistic, dull, and mostly static landscape while sleepy electronic sounds are dynamically generated by the player's surroundings.  Sometimes, the season will change, and new sounds will play.  It feels more like a palliative treatment for patients recovering from severe brain damage, and it is difficult for me to believe that even its most ardent supporters have honestly enjoyed playing it for more than 30 minutes.  Personally, I checked out around 12 minutes.

content:
Posted: April 18
												Games can be many things.Games can challenge us, can be an outlet for our stresses and our boredom, and they are absolutely wonderful for that ability. They can be exciting, gripping, and engaging, certainly. They can demand your full attention, and hold you, breathless with anticipation, spellbound by the compulsion to uncover more of their world, to play the next match, the next level, the next moment. They are magical, in the way they can draw the player in and keep them engaged despite the challenges they may present and the stress they can occasionally cause.But games can also draw stress out of us, too. They can soothe, they can relax, and they can even heal. Certainly, they can provide a distraction, and often... that's enough.And Proteus makes a wonderful distraction in that regard. It isn't much in the way of mechanics -- you generate a new world and wake up there, free to wander around and explore it. That's all there really is to it -- seeing what comes next, seeing what the world has to offer as it changes and evolves over the days and the seasons is its own reward, and some people may find that off-putting. Certainly, those people are entitled to their preferences, as well.But others may find in Proteus the exact break they need from whatever they've been playing recently, a quiet escape away from everything else nagging them in worlds both real and fictional. There is beauty in simplicity, and sparse mechanics executed well can be better than feature-rich experiences with less polish, to the right person. I happened to really enjoy this game personally (and do pardon my playtime, I tend to be an offline player in most things.) As to whether or not you might enjoy this -- if you want to interact and get into the nitty-gritty of things, you may wind up diappointed here. Walking around and sightseeing is the brunt of what you will find in Proteus' gameplay offerings. Those who already enjoy walking simulators will feel right at home so long as the art style appeals to you! For anyone left undecided, all I can advise is that if you think you will enjoy it, with the knowledge of how the game operates fresh in memory -- if you need a break from your traditional fare or you feel drawn to this game -- give it a chance, grab it on sale if you can, and see how you feel about things. I hope you find what you're looking for in it. I certainly have found an appreciated sojourn, here, and for that reason I recommend this game.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2013
												Well what can you say? If I ever did acid this would be the game to play. Its very well............spiritual.  Cycles of life, wonders of life, possibly the ending embraces death? Hard to say really, its your journey and what you make of it.  There is no game play, this all experiences only. You glide in any direction on this every changing island. I wont spoil it and tell you how you move from season to season but Im sure you'll get it.  Follow the light? Let it embrace you?  Probably the strangest title Ive ever played but certainly worth it. Environment creates the music, entities are charming. Some seem to die during different seasons but that speculation on my part. You take from the game what you personally experience.  Scary actually at certain points and nothing changed really but the lighting. I think it shows you the joy of life, how it changes, how to appreciate seasons, and a hint possibly that death is more than just death.  Took me 40 minutes to get through to what I can only guess was the end. Nothing dramatic, no epic end story. You just know its the end when you see it. Certainly will go through this again to see if the experiences are different per play through but first time through was pretty joyful. You smile a lot, frown a lot, seem even sad at times. There is no playing this game, there is only experiencing whatever message you take from it. I can only say my experience said this. Life is beautiful, seasons are beautiful, life is way to short, and maybe death is not as scary as it seems to be.Certainly your experience or what you take from it will be different.

												Proteus is a beautiful, emotionally rewarding game with wonderful graphics and beautiful music; any discussion of it's status as a 'Game' is an academic one at best, a distraction at worst.There is interaction, there is game play, there is a progression and an end to the game (  you use the stone circle on each island to progress from one season to the next and after four seasons the game ends with what may be death but if so it is an infinitely peaceful death after a few days of bliss  )and for these reasons I have no hesitation in recommending this as a gameProteus is one of the most beautiful games I have ever played.

												Art... Blah...Heres the thing. Most 'Art' games bug the hell out of me because of two big reasons. Theres a lot of them that seem devoid of any meaning or message and instead 'Look Pwetty'. Then you get ones that just go so arty, they forget the whole 'Game' part.Sadly for me, this hits both issues hard. Yes Proteus is quite pretty at times, the music soothing occasionally, however theres just no story, no message and nothing informative at all. That would be fine by itself to be honest but then theres the total lack of interactivity bar of walking about and staring at repeated patterns, trees that kind of look similar, cloned flowers and pixel bunnies. For some I imagine this title is a great thing, a soothing massage of a title. For me its just dull and devoid of anything to keep me entertained for over a few minutes. In fact, if you have noticed I have yet to even call this a game once here. Thats because it isnt and, just not for me.

												I do not recomend this game. It's a short little pixelated mess. That's not meant to be too much on the graphics, they were going for pixels and they scored. It's a very bright game. I might give it to someone who was depressed if they liked minecraft and were tired of challenge.I'll tell you what I think they were trying to do before I explain why I believe that they failed at it. What I believe they were trying to do is create a unique experience where you didn't have to do anything, you were just out on a walk (that happens to start out on the ocean). It seems like you arrive by boat to admire the pretty scenery and get to see the seasons change. It's meant to be a work of art, a road of many different directions with many different sights and a host of different experiences.I've actually looked, I can't find anyone who's found anything to do. The guides could be one sentence long: find fairy circles. That's all well and good but this game offers little up front. I tried to play it for the sound and scenery but you don't get medatitve, you get board.Do I recommend this game? No, I recommend playing minecraft with a seasons mod installed. At least then you won't be bathing in the "artwork" and will be able to look up again and admire how it is the world changes around us as we get so wrapped up in the little things that suddenly seem so insignificant. This does not. This makes me feel like I should go on walks more.Now here's what went wrong: I came into this game with no expectations. I heard it was an art game, so I expected it to challenge my perceptions on a game. That it did. There's no levels, no challenge, you're just on a walk with nothing to do. And that's where the problems begin: There's nothing to do. There's no new trees to find, there's no new experiences. I walked around for the entire time I played, I even abandoned the little goal the set for it (stepping in fairy circles to advance the seasons so you can see your island for a whole year? What?) and tried to see what the game offered. I found nothing. If that were their goal, they might as well have put things in it for you to do. They didn't have to exclude content for the sake of making a point, but they did. This is less a treatise on human nature and more a dull walk through the woods. I don't think adding some optional activities would have

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Have you ever played a game where the mechanics were so rich you felt like you could refine the entire thing into one concept and it would still be great? That feeling may work for many games but most of the time you won’t find out one way or the other. Most designers and gamers alike understand that games are an amalgamation of many ideas rather than a thoroughly impressive one-trick pony. This understanding seems to have evaded the creators of Proteus, or maybe they thought their game was exempt. Proteus is a one-concept tech demo that might’ve been neat if it was part of something bigger but what’s there isn’t enough to keep your interest or justify the seemingly inoffensive price.The concept of Proteus is relatively brief. You control a first-person character that starts off in the ocean with an island in sight on the horizon. Once you get to the island, your only source of interaction is what you walk next to. The game reacts to your presence by playing different music depending on your location and occasionally there is a sprite animal or insect that runs away from you. That is the entire game. There is “progression” and an “endpoint,” but not in the way you might hope for. Endings are usually synonymous with finales or closing thoughts. Proteus’ ends a lot like a High School final project. They probably could’ve kept prolonging it for a better grade but the class already lost interest and the teacher gave a glance that implied what they had was good enough.That’s not to say that “good enough,” is actually any good. Proteus’ quality hinges on the music and visuals, neither of which is very impressive. The artwork may be appealing in screenshots, but the environment remains completely static during gameplay. There are occasional lighting effects which add a bit of variety but nothing to make up for the overall stiffness of the game. As a result, the world feels very lifeless and the lack of interaction from the player doesn’t help. The music doesn’t add much personality either. Proteus’ concept of “different music plays depending where you are” certainly works but the sounds you’re hearing sound like placeholders rather than actual music. Most of the tracks sound like someone pressing buttons to see if the instrument is working rather than playing actual music. This blunder contributes to the feeling that Proteus is an undeveloped tech demo, not an actual game.If you somehow “finish” Proteus, you won’t be getting much more from the experience than the person who loads it up for five minutes and closes it out of disinterest. This game may be the latest discussion in the “are games art” debate but I’d argue that Proteus offers absolutely nothing to the player. There is no interaction to speak of, the music is amateurish, the visuals are mediocre and the experience is pointless. There is no message or mood established in Proteus, it’s the definition of wasting time. Proteus may serve as inspiration for a mechanic that’s a part of a bigger game, but on its own there’s nothing worth playing.

There are animals and plants, weather effects, and a day/night/seasonal cycle, all of which sync with a hypnotic, throbbing, synthy electronic soundtrack. It's trippy and pleasant and if you plug in some headphones and stare hard at the screen, can be pretty compelling and immersive.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Proteus – a game about walking… Yeah that’s it. Obviously I’m not a fan, but let’s get into the details (or lack thereof). If you haven’t heard of this game don’t be alarmed, I had not heard of it either until I purchased the one of the Humble Indie Bundles.When you first start playing, you appear in the ocean and begin to walk towards an island, imagine if you will, Minecraft, with no features, no running, no jumping, no enemies, no crafting, building, etc… Absolutely nothing, just walking and looking. What I later found out, was that you need to find a circle of stones to change the seasons over allowing you to look at a different color pallet of the trees, grass, and bugs. Hence the main narrative is to progress through the seasons. Hmm okay, so I can finish the game by standing in the circle afk. Ah! but beating the game isn’t the primary focus, no, we should experience this transcendental artistic expression of man as the changing of seasons, the absolution and solidarity of this naturalistic soul trapped on a lonely island; how profound?! And to think, I was just a meek imbecile, a dim-witted brute until I experienced this revolutionary journey.Alright so maybe I’m being a little sarcastic and acting like a♥♥♥♥♥♥ and I will give it that it looks ‘pretty’, but this is only in the sense of the color schemes chosen associated with the seasons, other than that the world is fairly generic. There are dips and valleys, hills and mountains, and they are all, respectively, not too deep or too tall, but just average. Occasionally you will find roads, tombstones, a house, a strange black polygonal shape, and even an assortment of wildlife, but so what, it is just an assortment of objects to look at. Why incorporate anything into this visual discourse? it all feels like a generic, ancient, simplistic, fantasy world. For instance, maybe there was an old tribal village that existed at some point but it’s one of those things that is left for interpretation. I will say, that I was pleased to see the existence of actual music, (I’m surprised they decided that was worth keeping). And yes, the music was fitting in a sense. But I could not help feel that it was little too intrusive, coupled with the lack of substance in the ‘gameplay’ it all just feels forced, it needed more ambiance and less 8-bit digital.And that’s about it. I mean seriously, they actually charge money for this, and no I do not want to here “Oh, it’s an art game, it’s supposed to have no plot or gameplay.” How is this even a retort, I thought all games were art, how come if I say Lord of the Rings: Conquest is a terrible game, no one will resort to the “but it’s art” defense. Most people will say, “I had fun playing it.” And there is your key word, ‘play’, it is a game and it is art, but first and foremost it is and should be a game. This whole moronic idea of art games needs to be laid to rest, it is pretentious and egotistical. If you truly want to ‘play’ Proteus, here is what you do. Boot up Minecraft, download a simplistic colorful/seasonal texture pack, turn on some ambient music, generate a world and run around in creative mode occasionally changing the seasonal texture pack. No I do not recommend this game.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												The sluggish movement and bad camera design make this game tedious and frustrating.Touring a procedurally generated island would usually be a fun thing to do, but I wouldn't exactly call this exploring. The constant wrestling with the restrictive camera angle and the stifling walking speed makes this an exercise in patience. Instead of feeling free to explore, I feel claustrophobic.The camera cannot look up or down past a certain angle from the horizon. Looking down from a precipice or up at the tree isn't possible. Climbing up or descending steep slopes means the player can't watch where they're going, which feels very unnatural.The environment is nice enough from a distance, but the 2D sprites can be really immersion breaking. Tree branches rotate to constantly face the camera in that eerie fashion.The music is not good.The day-night cycles are much too quick, and the stars in the sky look very artificial.Some creatures just ignore collision detection.The default mouse settings has smoothing enabled, and only 10% sensitivity.

												The first time I treid to play this game, it crashed and then wouldn't load again. The next day I realized that it was still showing me as being in the game and logged 30+ hours of gameplay. I decided to close the process and actually give the game another shot... and I couldn't take more than 30 minutes of it. The crash was a blessing and I should have taken it as a sign. Sure, the game is surprisingly visually appealing, but its lack of gameplay barely qualifies it as a game. This is a pixelated walk in the park but substitute burning calories with killing braincells.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												UPDATE: Original "review" at the bottom of the current oneIt's been a little more than 2 years since I posted my original "review" for Proteus, and looking back I must say it was hardly a proper overview of this game. Just some loose, short and rather ambiguous opinions of the overall product as a whole, hardly anything constructive or informative, something that is unfortunately quite common in the review section, but it is definitely no excuse for producing a rather poor piece of writing regarding this particular product (even if I'm not a journalist, I should have tried harder). The problem is, that this type of game doesn't really suit me and does not match my preferences, something I didn't know before I tried it, and since I was unable to gain enjoyment out of this, I felt somewhat salty and decided to leave unfavorable opinion.I can definitely say that the graphics are really nice,and although they are simplistic, I think they are the perfect choice for this kind of game, because of their charm and the fact that they go extremely well with the soundtrack, that is dynamic and changes depending on what happens on the screen. But unfortunately this is how I perceive this game: simple (though pleasant) graphics accompanied by the appropriate, everchnaging soundtrack, and the only one can do is to explore the procedurally generated island, something that I, personally, wasn't captivated by and ultimately didn't enjoy. In the end, if I were to summarize my whole experience I would say that "It isn't my cup of tea."If you are considering the purchase of this game, I hope my thoughts can be of some use, maybe as another point of view, though I highly encourage you to read other reviews, as others explored the features of this game more extensively. And if you enjoyed this game, I must say that I am envious that it met your expectations, though I'm glad it did, as at the end of the day this is the most important part of all the gaming: to have fun.ORIGINAL REVIEW:While the idea is interesting, and the soundtrack is quite relaxing, "Proteus" gets boring really quick. The only thing player can do, is to walk around and observe the rather empty scenery. Seven euros is way too much for this game. To be honest, it doesn't deserve even half of the asked price.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Ethereal, Cathartic. Proteus is like is the Nintendo Entertainment System was a sentient beign and we were allowed to enter it's dreams. As someone who finds difficulty enjoying the flood of indie games that claim to be "installations", "a vessel for an interactive story" and "purely artistic expressions", such as Dinner Date and Dear Esther- Proteus seems to settle in a good place for me. You find yourself coming upon a randomly generated island, with music  that matches the environment and changes with your actions. There, you experience the island changing seasons, and interact with the different elements that come along with it- all in a relaxing exploration of a place that becomes more and more familiar and serene.And then it is gone.I highly reccomend wearing headphones and having a large screen or a multimonitor set up.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												This game is one of the better walking simulaters I have played but I hate to give it a negative review but I feel it has two issues. One issue I have is price.  It is difficult to price a "game" where there is nothing to the game itself.  There is walking and minor and I emphasize minor interactions.  For 9.99, I feel it is expensive for what it is.  Another issue I have with the game is the soundtrack.  It is an annoying soundtrack at best.  I feel it trys to do a bit of retro with some electronica and it does not sound good.  What I liked about the game was it isn't that long for a walking simulater and you walk at a decent pace which many similar games make you walk slow to extend the game time which is just annoying.  I would say get this game if you enjoy the non-game genre when this is on sale but to the regular gamer who wants have a compelling story or gameplay or other features that makes a game a video game, they would not enjoy this.
