number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2013
												After the first 10 or 20 minutes of  frustration, i feel strangely relaxing, and that's exactly what has hooked me at first. But no buttons, tools, task bars or hints, just your first person presence to meditate or something.But then i discovered little constants that leaded me to found the simple environment interactions, just activated by presence. Sounds, lights and movements, nothing more.The surprises really start to came when i began another world - procedurally generated, so they're never the same - and at the first night i heard a loud and strange sound, and then an owl flying from a tree to another. Curiosity catches me, and i found me exploring this an other worlds.And they reveal secrets, beautiful, but sometimes kind scary or supernatural.But to reach them you have to find how, because they're not random and as you discover it you can make it over and over as your wish and event conditions.It have a meaning - a naive and predictable one - and even a story with the same previous attributes, but you'll have to discover how to reach it. Like any other game, you'll learn the mechanics that led you till the end, doesn't matter how boring or stupid it sounds to me or you.Finally, to me Proteus - very personally saying it - has being an overwhelming experience, even after discovered all secrets. Now i use it to relax, making me - sometimes - feel me like a child pursuing birds, but in a "3d-like" 8bit magical world, with a deeply relaxing soundtrack that you, somewhat step in.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Visually the game is cool and nice to look at but it doesn't help with the experience due to bad controls and annoying music.People claim this game is nice to get you relaxed, something to play after a bad day etc... but no. This game doesn't relax you unless you turn off the sounds, which is like 90% of what this game is, the badly made 'music'. And the controls are horrible, the game is more likely to make you angry at the bad controls and constantly waiting for something to actually happen.A game like Dear Esther and the countless other exploration games and similar games are a lot better at relaxing you, and they are actually immersive. You can actually live into the worlds in those games, you can't in this one.There's not much to say as this game contains no actual content, it's a cool pixel graphics world with not-so-great 'music' that badly generates as you walk past triggers.And let me just slip this in, the options menu isn't horrible but extremely weird, it feels like they made it weird and kind of bad on purpose to differ themselves from the good options menu's most other games have.The world is nice to look at if you enjoy pixel graphics, that's the only compliment I can pull out of me. It's a nice world.This game is certainly experimental indeed and I hope the developers(and other aspiring developers) can learn what to not due via this game.I cannot recommend this game at any price, not even free.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												Pompus game with no gameplay, storyline, depth or intruigue.Its supposed to be a big world to explore and adventure and find interesting things without it being aggresive, dark or anything other than pleasant.What it ACTUALLY is is a teaspoon deep game where the entire world is copy and pasted with NOTHING interesting to see. I walked around for ages trying to give it a chance but there was just nothing there. They dont even give you the freedom to create your own fun or an enjoyable way of moving.The graphics are ok at best but overchildish.Gameplay is non-existant.Atmostphere is wafer thin.Storyline at its most complex is "Youre a guy who goes to look at rocks".What this is is a game which feels like it was made as a first test subject by a student but what it actually is is someone who doesnt understand what art is getting a basic understanding of games and throwing this together in a couple of hours (being generous).It aims for a mix of art and games and achieves neither.A cheap masturbatory aid for the creator who gets to sniff his own farts while massaging their own ego.I wouldnt give this to a child for fear of stunting their development.I wouldnt give this to a teen for them thinking this is acceptable behaviour.I wouldnt give this to an adult as we have enough♥♥♥♥♥♥to deal with without wasting our time with this.I wouldnt give this to an elderly person as Id hate for them to know the world they worked for had lead to this.I would give it to someone as a bad example.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												God awful.I don't know what compelled me to buy this game. All I can say for that is I have my own shortcomings. Gameplay is nonexistent - it's a walking simulator.Graphics look awful, especially when you look at certain objects like trees, and I don't mean that because it's pixelated. There are good ways to accomplish that art style, this ain't it.Audio quality is alright, making it the best thing about this game by a long shot.Now it's time for me to go into ranting. The section below has little to do with whether or not you should BUY this game, and everything to do with me being tired of seeing walking simulators tirelessly hoisted as the best gaming has to offerGames like this and Dear Esther are awful as games and as art. They're not games, they're virtual art exhibits, and that is the problem. If you think these games are art and the rest of gaming isn't, you are part of the problem. We view these games as art because it reminds us more of what we've already established long ago. They don't progress art except by saying "see, I can replicate the feeling of an incredibly boring film or art exhibit ON THE COMPUTER". They don't establish anything new. At all. Still, the knee-jerk reaction across almost the entire gaming press is to heap praise and worship it. Why? Because we tend to see older types of media as having more artistic merit by default. Books are seen as having more worth than movies, movies as having more merit than games. Dear Esther, Proteus, Gone Home, and the entire library of pretentious indie titles only serve to play along with this by regressing gaming to feel more like old media, even if it's with new messages and perspectives.How about instead of praising walking simulator after walking simulator as shining examples of games as art, we instead hoist up games that actually use more aspects unique to gaming?

												A mind-numbing, heacache induced art student nightmare, a game with almost zero gameplay, replay value, characters, or infact anything of any real tangible entertainment value and nothing more to offer beyond the stylized visuals. A pretentious person will tell you this is beautiful - Do not be fooled. This is the artier and more pompous end of the Call of Duty spectrum. If you want a "walk around and look at things" game that is actually worth while, play Dear Esther, which is a moody, atmospheric "experience" game much like this only it doesn't have an utterly intolerable degree of pretentiousness and fart-sniffery. It's a dark, ambiguous journey through a wind-swept isle which still maintains a certain degree of pretentiousness but is a thousand times less irritating about it than this dayglow eyesore. Avoid like cancer.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2013
												Much like my own life, Proteus is rather colourful but remarkably empty and dull.Seemingly another failed attempt to further the 'games as art' concept, right alongside Dear Esther and Thirty Flights of Loving, these are all hobby projects that frankly did not merit commercialization. A 'game' that doesn't even last 40 minutes, with interaction literally limited to 'turn' and 'move forward', seems a bit reaching to ask $5 for, much less $10.That said, if you REALLY like looking at pretty colour palettes in a pseudo-8-bit environment, it might be worth picking up on sale.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
												This is the worst purchase I ever done, it doesn't even count as a game. 10euro for a pixel forest simulator. The game has a very odd pixel style to it which annoys me. The games does not have a goal and is boring as hell. It also have a pretty high metascore (80/100) because it's "beautiful" and "artistic"  game with a "fantastic" pixel graphic. But no one can seriously enjoy playing this game. It's like modern art; you own a painting of something weird like three straight lines and a circle. You don't even think the painting is beautiful and it's only hanging on your wall so that the people visiting you thinks you are artistic and sophisticated. You are refusing to have real beautiful paintings of landscapes and such where you can actually see that the artist but effort into making it.Sure go full indie hipster on this game, but don't trick other people to buy this game because you want to sound like a modern art hipster critic. "Oh it's colorful has no goal and is ugly as♥♥♥♥♥♥ this must be the game of the year" - a random indie hipsters first impression.  The pixel style and the "no goal" thing is just a result of lazy game developers. But they are not stupid! They knew that all indie hipsters would go full ape♥♥♥♥♥♥on something colorful and simplistic and give it 10/10 on metascore and call it the game of the century. I'm generous and I give this game 0/10

Does the forward button go forward?  I think that's a critical aspect to having a good game.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2013
												There is simply nothing here....I bought this game after I had finished "Dear Esther" because that game had changed the way I view games as art. This came onto Steam riding the heels of "Dear Esther" and billed itself as the same type of "artistic experience" of a game.I will say again that there is simply nothing here. The world you enter is bland and uneventful with zero interaction or goal. It wouldn't be so bad if the world itself was pretty to look at but using this pixelated 4 bit art style was a cheap cop-out to knock something out quick and call it art.The game fails on so many levels it's not even funny.I'm not looking for world interaction or a definitive goal in artistic styled games, but this simply is devoid of anything at all!This piece of tripe is something that the developers should be ashamed that they charge money for.....even if it was free (which it should have been in the first place) I would still say that the 91mb  it took to download it would be a waste of bandwidth.ABSOLUTE FAIL!

Posted: January 8, 2014
												Interesting. Relax and explore. That's all there is to this. Glad I spent the 2 bucks on it while it was on sale. I'd probably feel less than satisfied if I'd paid full price, but for just a couple bucks, it was worth it. It's not a game. It's interactive art, but there are some interesting things to discover as you explore.  I feel that this is the sort of thing that the minds behind Flower and Journey might have made had they been much more limited in budget. If you enjoy these sorts of experiences and you find it on sale, give it a go. If you're the sort of gamer who must always have stated goals, achievements, weapons and power-ups, move on. You'll be happier spending your money elsewhere.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												This is a game in which there are no enemies to defeat or problems to solve. Your only goal is to explore. Every time you play a new island is randomly generated. The island will have its own seasons, weather, and day/night cycles. There will also be some wildlife that will react to your presence in various ways. The soundtrack will react to your location (under a rain cloud, on top of a mountain, ect.).This is a "walking simulator" game, and while I have no problem with walking simulator games per se (see my positive review of Dear Esther) I can't really recommend buying Proteus. The island of Dear Esther was interesting to explore because the graphics were AAA quality and the music was top notch. But Proteus suffers from low res pixel graphics (seen one pixelated tree, seen em all), a simplistic soundtrack, and the lack of interesting stuff to see. I played 20 minutes of Proteus and felt I had seen 95% of what the game had to offer; I felt no incentive to wait another 10 minutes to see what few changes the next season might bring.Fortunately I paid just a few cents for it, and those 20 minutes I did play were enjoyable, so it wasn't a total wash. If you like exploration games and you see Proteus on sale for a few cents you might give it a try, but I wouldn't pay more than that.

												I got this on sale for $2.  While I wouldn't have spent $10 on it, there's no remorse in purchasing this game for less than the cost of a large bag of chips. I can keep it there and come back to it from time to time with no guilt.Now, from someone who DID NOT enjoy Dear Esther, I do like this.  It's fun to just walk around.  Laugh because I made the little square bees angry, or something.  Unlike Dear Esther, which has lofty, pretentious aims, this is just there to let you relax, and doesn't pretend to be anything more.  It's the squishy stress ball of games.  At no point will you be stuck on x area, looking for some stupid bauble, or trying to get the game to trigger an event by doing the right hoohah dance, or whatever.  Grab it while it's $2, and play it when you're too stressed to even handle conventional game play.  (You KNOW that happens.)

												I've always been a sucker for games like these. At first I wondered if the 9 euros I put down was a mistake. 												who signed off on this? this is the type of game you show to your uncle after your  aunt (his wife) has just passed away. although the funeral isn't till thursday, he insists on staying over three nights prior (monday), and just by consequence of his very existence, you become desperate to show your extracurricular activities are not damaging. "why it's a procedurally-generated landscape of terrible textures and audio trigger points, that lacks any intrigue, and in which nothing at all happens." he sighs, plays it for FIVE freakin' hours. you sleep downstairs with the un-killable cat; cursing the plan, the game, your aunt (his wife), the whole world.post: i would like to add that the concept is a lovely one, it's just the execution that is lacking. i feel as though an experience like this should have some semblance of longetivity. for me at least, it didn't. one set of rolling hills blended into the other and any sense of discovery soon disappeared.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												This game reminds me of a time in my teens, going to the fair and paying money to peek in a majestic aquarium and see a mermaid. I don't know what I actually thought I'd see, probably nothing amazing, but it ended up being a really ugly old fat man in a one piece bathing suit and an XXL long sleeve green tshirt around "her" legs, sitting at the bottom of a disguised dunk tank. I paid one dollar and fifty cents to see that man and this game disappointed me more. Its exactly what you'd expect, except with less going on. It's peaceful, but if that's what you're into, hiking in real life is free at a lot of places and the rabbits are more than 4 pixels. It was the anticipation that made me hate it, if I just stumbled across this for free, coded into a web page, I'd probably play for five minutes and then stop and be like, "Hey, that was sort of cool."You can press Q, and it auto-walks forward, and you just look around with the mouse with really not much other than trees to see, aside from a few graves, and the changing time of day. I think a lot of people are arguing that this is art, or this game is just trying to be different and show that you don't need goals or objectives, but from my perspective, many of those people are just fighting the norm, playing the devil's advocate. I can't see someone spending more than 20 minutes max on this game.Overall: 2/10 for being pretty.

The sun was bright, and everything was fine and fun.  When night came, I eagerly went towards the place that triggers season change, wanting to see more wonderful and whimsical things.Autumn came, and I ran about looking for stuff to chase.  I found the dragonflies among the grass, weakly twitching on the ground, clearly dying.I quit the game for the rest of the day.

												Proteus isn't your typical game, as has been stated by many reviews now. That said, if you give it the time it deserves, it will be a rewarding experience. It's basically a walking simulator, you're on an island and how you interact with the world around you (read: where you walk/how you explore/do you explore) is really up to you. I do strongly recommend playing the game with sound -it really adds to the experience. I, for one, spent a great deal of the first season chasing after various critters simply because of the sounds they made.Good way to relax, definitely worth the time. Give it a shot, if nothing else you can enter the debate of "is this really a game"! ;)

												Amazing. Absolutely fantastic. It's relaxing, it's beautiful, and it made me smile with glee on more than one occasion. Posted: January 6, 2014
												Proteus isn't a "game" as noted in many other reviews. It's an exploration through 4 seasons on a procedurally generated island. While this in itself isn't a bad thing, there simply isn't enough to see to justify buying it. If it were an early access game or some sort of tech demo or something, I'd say give it a shot if you're bored. But your money would be much better spent on another game. If you want to do some exploring, go down to a local park. There'll be much more to see than Proteus has to offer.

Posted: December 6, 2015
												For me, this game had a big focus on what you should follow in life. You start off with a large unexplored island full of life, and you end off with just the moon being the only thing to guide you. Everyone need something to guide us, and this game has alot of examples of it. I found myself aimlessly wandering around, looking at the beautifull landmarks, only to get lost after a while, but when the night came, a large vortex of light swarmed away into a direction.I followed, and when i got to the end, i found a large stone circle that changed the seasons. When it was done changing, it went all dark. The trees were dead. The life was gone, and the island was full of gravestones. The music changed into a dull string of nothingness. The things i used to guide me around the island were gone. With nothing to guide me, i wandered away from the island, With nothing happening, i went back again, but this time, it seemed that the island was a bit small, but to my surprise, i was flying. Higher and higher, until i saw the only landmark to guide me; The moon. The screen went dark.

Posted: September 21, 2014
												I recommend this, but only under certain circumstances.1. You enjoy art 2. You get it at a good priceAnd yes.... there is an "ending" to this "game".While I wouldn't give it a whole hearted thumbs up to the sky, it's worth a play. A lot of people won't get it or understand the concept. But it's more a work of interactive art than a game. At first I thought there wasn't a point to it till I noticed I was in a way... "leveling up". After getting the hang of it I reached a point where I was slowly lifted up to the air and the game ended and started over.It's not as story or emotionally driven as other art style games like Flower or Journey on PS3, but it's an amusing piece of work with fun visuals and sound. You just have to get lost in it.

Posted: August 27, 2014
												This is an incredible experience.I am not usually one for things billed as "relaxation".  I literally cannot count to ten for the purpose of relaxing my mind; the attempt triggers very unpleasant memories for me, which I guess I won't go into here.  I regard essentially everything - nature audio recordings, massage, etc - billed on those merits with extreme skepticism.Proteus is in a different league.  A true meditative experience.  Also a rumination on aloneness and what it means, which is very close to the core thing I need to come to terms with in my own life, so it's really wonderful to play.The visuals are already really beautiful, but the audio takes it above and beyond.  I played around with it for about half an hour and found a bunch of stuff, but not everything, according to the forums.  I'll probably go back another day - this is strong stuff, and I can't do too much at once! - but it would have easily been worth the $10 even for the one session.Thank you.

Posted: September 6, 2014
												Proteus is art, but it is not a game. If you like the concept of intrigue and immersion while walking around a funny little island, then get this game.That being said, if you're looking for a point, steer clear because there is none. All you do is walk around looking at trees, creatures, and monoliths. There isn't an ending, and it doesn't really qualify as a game. It's artsy, so if you're like me and you're looking for direction or things to do, you don't want this kind of limited experience.I recommend it because while I didn't particularly gel with the purpose of Proteus, I can appreciate the purpose and the time spent creating it; hell, each island is randomly generated which has gotta be worth something. That said, though, 10 bucks is a bit much. If the price drops to say, 5 dollars, or less, I would say give it a try. 5 bucks is the price of a hamburger. Really not a total loss, even if you didn't fully enjoy the game.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												Pixels, art, exploration, seasons, and relaxation are what make up Proteus. In this game your thrown out in a area of water and have to "swim" to shore. More like move to it. Anyways, once you get on the island there are many sights to see. Jumping um... frogs, crabs, little weird plant people that get scared then pop back up, seasons, structures, twinkly star shiny orby things (most of the stuff I just really can't tell what it should be called), all sorts of wonderous trees, and at the end a wonderful light show (the game's depiction of the aurora borealis). It has wonderful music to go along with the game's many sights. I truly enjoyed the game despite a short playthrough time and I would say average replay value unless you want to discover every little detail of the island generation which I personally wish to do sometime soon. Overall the game may take 45 minutes to two hours depending how long you spend in each season. The 10 USD (~7 EURO) price tag is a little large for this game, so I would wait for a sale like I did so you can get Proteus for a fifth of that price. To sum it all up, Proteus is a great island exploration simulation with wonderful music and sights that would be best to buy during a sale.

Posted: June 8, 2013
												Kind of like a 320x200 video game rendering of "Koyaanisqatsi." Not just because its primary appeal is its visuals, but also because of its pretty neat, procedurally generated, Phillip Glass-esque score. The primary mechanic is exploration and the combination of the audio and visuals make it play more like a sort of extended tone poem than a "game," but there are interactive elements and new things to see and discover on different playthroughs. Not sure if there's enough there to warrant many play throughs, but it is incredibly....relaxing. Its cumulative effect is a bit like popping a couple valium and listening to one of those self-hypnosis relaxation tapes (which wouldn't be a compliment if referring to most games, but in Proteus' case it is). In fact, it's so relaxing that I kind of find the demand to control it to be a bit of an impediment at times. Someone needs to make an "auto-wander" mod for it so I could turn it on and veg out when I'm stressed or just fall asleep to it.

Posted: July 20, 2013
												Commenting on a game like this almost requires someone with a proper sense of poetry, because artful words are necessary to communicate the experience.  Proteus isn't a "game" in any sense of the word but rather a literal experience to discover and explore.  To that end I encourage you to play this in a manner which best allows you to immerse yourself and let Proteus BE your world for a little while.  Play in the dark with headphones on and toss out your preconceived ideas for what you should see and do.  If you can approach Proteus in this way you'll find a tangible sense of wonder and intrigue as you are presented with details that are both familiar (land, trees, mountains) and unfamiliar like pixel presentations that alter your perception of what's normal along with an everpresent sense of music and interplay as your participation in the world changes the experience.  There are sights and things here to capture your imagination if you spend the time to take the world on its own terms.  With that being said Proteus is rather short and repetitive.  The whole world is procedurally generated which in theory means that every time you play you'll be greeted with an entirely different island than you ever visited before, but there are certain rules about the lay of the land which remain consistent and so the wonderful sense of new discovery can fade over repeated plays.  This doesn't diminish the enjoyment of the game any more than repeated trips to your favorite campground at a national park can make you tired of going back, but one of the primary appeals is that sense of discovery where you're confronted with a world that's simultaneously familiar but alien. ...so despite playing the game several times now I still feel like there's more yet I haven't found.  I'll come back again.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												Let's get one thing straight from the beginning - Proteus isn't a game. It's an experience. It combines two elements - sound and vision - to create a uniquely moving and personal experience as you roam a small island. You don't do anything. You explore your own personal world, one that teems with surprises. You won't forget the first time you walk through a creaking forest at night and an owl hoots at you form a nearby tree. Nor will you forget the first time you stepped atop a mountain. The first sunrise actually set the hairs on my arms on end.It's about exploring what Proteus has to offer with your eyes and ears. Both sounds and sights are simultaneously abstract and magnificent, drawing the traveller deeper in. You could find yourself chasing a bunny for the strong notes it creates versus a melodic background, or simply sitting under a tree watching a sunset, admiring the view and ambience.As I said, Proteus is an experience - if you don't give it the time it deserves, you won't feel it as you should, you won't be drawn in as the developers intended. If you want instant gratification, go play CoD. But if you want something a little deeper, a little more personal, something that isn't all about the numbers, give Proteus a try.Starman

												Picked up Proteus when it was on sell recently for 2 dollars. I didn't know what to expect with this game, and honestly that is a good thing. I recommend this game to anyone who doesn't have any expectations of it. Confused? Well let me explain. Proteus is a game about exploring and experiencing an island. It gets a tiny bit more complicated and it's not the same experience every time, but that is pretty much it. It is one of those games where the journey is more rewarding than the end. I did like the game though, so honestly if you can catch it on sale and would just like a nice, friendly, relaxing game to poke around at this is one I'd say to give it a go. It's cute, fun, whimsical, and just a nice way to relax.

Posted: January 14, 2014
												In short: This is what happens if minecraft swallowed windows Paint and replaced combat and building with dynamic sound and visuals. I don't think it is bad, just different. Look, let's not B.S ourselves this is very much an "art" game in the style of Journey and Brothers: A tale of two sons. There's no enemies to fight and your goal is just to mess about. It's meant to be a meditation piece as something you do to relax and want to see pretty colors. I remember I kept thinking how much it reminds me of minecraft for obvious reasons, but like the afformentioned games it can be really beautiful to sit by the large tree on autumn night and see the fox peering at you curiously. Proteus builds itself on little moments. I can imagine this being an excercise for buddhists, because it really shows how we break down when we have no objective or goal to reach. Where you simply sit and appriciate the world and it's beauty.I sound like a hippie, but the simple truth is you need to be in the right mindset. I came to play this after some darker themed games like Dishonored and Papers, Please and I felt it a nice change of scenery. Honestly the game shouldn't take you more than 90 minutes to see everything.Don't expect something new and innovative with this game. It's a boring at times and it's easy to get lost and not understand what you are doing. In that fact there is a beauty though, because it forces you to use your imagination like retro games did. If you have and open mind and are in the mood for something upbeat, simple, and fairly pretentious I recommend it. You might be suprised when you start noticing themes like life death and change, that standards themes of "art games", but done uniquely enough to be interesting. p.s  I WISH THERE WAS A RUN FUNCTION OMG<ASDFHFGasnduivonajwkdbnfuilawdsivblYIWL... *sigh*

												Proteus is, in my opinion, the most beautiful game I have ever played. It's a quiet game about exploring and experiencing an unknown world. In this world, you are rewarded for your curiosity--but not in the "bonus points" and "level up" sort of reward. Instead, your reward for what you discover is the very witnessing of what you've uncovered. The world is fully immersive if you let it be--immaculately gorgeous and warmly sonorous. Proteus is a game that asks for your wonder. If you give it, you will experience something both comfortably familiar and excitingly new.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												This game's very design--from the curious yet delightful sounds, soft and pleasant colors, and soul-quelling music, to the way the player's screen enters and exits the game like eyes slowly opening and closing--is meant to be strongly reminiscent of a dream; a beautiful, subjective dream. A dream where the more you get lost within, the more you get lost within your own thoughts. Abandon the day-to-day burdens of goals, duties, tasks, competition, opposition, and reward--the values that our workaholic, robotic, and disconnected society holds so dear. Abandon those--just for a few moments, and take the time to bask yourself into consciousness within another plane. Take the time to simply... be.

There are small creatures to interact with, that are cute  and have sound that meshes so perfectly with the music from your surroundings, and it's nice to have something that doesn't involve killing and that has no dark storyline. Overall just a fantastic game.

Posted: January 6, 2014
												Proteus isn't a "game" as noted in many other reviews. It's an exploration through 4 seasons on a procedurally generated island. While this in itself isn't a bad thing, there simply isn't enough to see to justify buying it. If it were an early access game or some sort of tech demo or something, I'd say give it a shot if you're bored. But your money would be much better spent on another game. If you want to do some exploring, go down to a local park. There'll be much more to see than Proteus has to offer.

Posted: May 17, 2014
												I had just finished a stressful match of League of Legends and I decided that I needed to take a breather, so I loaded up Steam and remembered I had just bought this game as apart of a Humble Bundle. Figuring that it could be good, I installed it, put on my headphones, and dove in. Waking up waist deep in the pixelated ocean, I was immersed in a simple yet utterly beautiful world. I watched day turn to night and night turn to day. There were no goals, nor any rules of what I had to do. I walked around an island, listening to the world. I climbed a mountain and heard the sea wind blowing. I walked into the rain and heard a gentle drizzle land on the nearby trees. As I played-- no, not played. As I experienced Proteus, I felt my muscles relieve themselves, and even now do I feel utterly calm. I can't explain this game, because it's not a game. Walking through Proteus was a reminder that the world is beautiful, and all we have to do is take time to see it.

Posted: December 19, 2014
												Proteus is less a game and more an experience, but it is surely a grand one. If you can play it with an open mind, not getting hung up on the fact that there are virtually no objectives, you will have a wonderful experience. If you play games merely for the difficulty, thrill, or highscores, this is not the game for you. Being a game of exploration, Proteus will obviously be the best during its first playthrough. I recommend playing when it's dark so you can turn out all the lights, wear headphones, and get immersed in this quirky world of sounds and creatures. It is truly a unique and pleasurable experience. I have even played Proteus as a means to relieve stress, and it works. This game is well worth the $10 price tag.

I'm fine just walking around in either Skyrim or Minecraft, just observing, so long as I am choosing to do that and can stop doing that at any time. Posted: January 7, 2014
												I got this on sale for $2.  While I wouldn't have spent $10 on it, there's no remorse in purchasing this game for less than the cost of a large bag of chips.  It's also about 90MB, which meant it was playable within minutes, and isn't taking up a huge amount of space on my machine.  I can keep it there and come back to it from time to time with no guilt.Now, from someone who DID NOT enjoy Dear Esther, I do like this.  It's fun to just walk around.  Laugh because I made the little square bees angry, or something.  Unlike Dear Esther, which has lofty, pretentious aims, this is just there to let you relax, and doesn't pretend to be anything more.  It's the squishy stress ball of games.  At no point will you be stuck on x area, looking for some stupid bauble, or trying to get the game to trigger an event by doing the right hoohah dance, or whatever.  Grab it while it's $2, and play it when you're too stressed to even handle conventional game play.  (You KNOW that happens.)

Posted: August 25, 2013
												who signed off on this? this is the type of game you show to your uncle after your  aunt (his wife) has just passed away. although the funeral isn't till thursday, he insists on staying over three nights prior (monday), and just by consequence of his very existence, you become desperate to show your extracurricular activities are not damaging. "what exactly is this?", he asks between sobs. you slide the headphones over his ears. "why it's a procedurally-generated landscape of terrible textures and audio trigger points, that lacks any intrigue, and in which nothing at all happens." he sighs, plays it for FIVE freakin' hours. you sleep downstairs with the un-killable cat; cursing the plan, the game, your aunt (his wife), the whole world.post: i would like to add that the concept is a lovely one, it's just the execution that is lacking. i feel as though an experience like this should have some semblance of longetivity. for me at least, it didn't. one set of rolling hills blended into the other and any sense of discovery soon disappeared.

												To the game's credit, it has very nice ambient sound/music. It adds additional little notes and melodies that play depending what you're looking at or near and what's happening, and that part is very nicely done. All in all though, I found this game a bit of a let down. The environments are too repetetive to make exploration a very rich experience for more than the first couple minutes, and the game itself is over very quickly. I finished it without feeling like I had explored much of anything, without feeling like I had felt deeply relaxed or enjoyed any beautiful scenery, without feeling like anything interesitng had been communicated to me via sublte symbolism - more or less feeling like I'd barely played a game at all. I feel like the use of audio in this game shows a lot of creativity and potential, but unfortunately there's not much else to see here. I'm afraid I've got to agree with the reviews saying you've basically played the game by watching the trailer.

Posted: February 23, 2015
												2015 edition, Might make you smile and cry. Depends how much you read into it I guess. Had a review for this title once, felt it was too childish as it was, but it came from the feeling the game gave me. Now I'm writing a short one again as I finish the game a second time. I did not live to see the aurora this time...It's a brief walk on a small island. Four different seasons to see and listen. Until the end. That's it. For some it's just that and bit boring. For me. It's like watching the Snowman cartoon as a child  for the first time during christmas time. It's like stepping into the forest of Mononoke Hime for a brief moment or strolling in the woods of Mushishi. The visuals, music and sound in complete control of my mood. It's pretty hard to rate or explain stuff like that. Obviously things like this won't work always like charm, but it did twice for me.I just wish someone could take stuff like this and put it into a longer and more complete package.

Posted: February 23, 2015
												Deep within the shadow of a memory of a dream you once had, you recall an island, familiar to you and yet foreign. Awakening offshore you stumble onto the beach, the light of a Spring sun above you. All about you is music of your making, a strange beautiful melody crafted merely by your presence here. The notes drift through the air, tumble through the leaves of the trees and blow wistfully through the grass with the wind.As night falls, you walk among fireflies, following a trail of standing stones that hum and mumble as you touch them. With the moon high above, you find a ring of the mumbling stones, and inside the warm light of the fireflies dances in a circle with your tune... the world begins to change...10/10 would do shrooms again. Also Proteus is a great game.

Posted: December 11, 2014
												Number one; this is an intensely buggy game. All it did for the first few months of my owning it was crash almost immediately when it was opened. It was only through some vague whim that I happened to try and load it again ages after purchasing it.While I fear I will be accused of missing the point, I must admit to finding Proteus utterly pointless. It is less a game, than a screen-saver and must be regarded as unfinished, laziness, as opposed to avant-garde, 'higher-meaning', indie game. Not all games need a crude starting line and a goal, but they need something more than the Emeperors Clothes that this game is evidently adorned in. Proteus is a meandering and ultimately unnecessary experience for anyone to have. It's only use might be to gently ease people back into society after some horrible, drug-addled. breakdown, but it's certainly not as a videogame. When you finally exit Proteus, the pixels make for an eye-closing animation; but my real eyes had already done that long ago. It was like a trip to the shops, only with less to show for it; I could have got a pint of milk during all of that pointlessness.

Posted: February 22, 2014
												To start I would like to say that I love indie gaming and am not one of those individuals who feels you truly have to define "what a game" is by scores, or quests. However the trend may have been taken to far with proteus. This is one of those games that is just supposed to lull you to sleep with its calming environments and harmonious sounds, which I can dig. I mean Flower really got the genre off the ground doing the same thing. Proteus is not Flower. It costs the same. But is nothing close to Flower.Proteus as a whole feels empty to me. It starts of for the first minute as this lush world of beauty and quickly diminishes once you realize that it doesnt go any where from there. The sounds and views wont change at all from what you first see wandering onto the island and only get worse as the seasons pass. Fall and Winter are actually depressing in this depiction. The sounds themselves actually made me more annoyed than anything being high pitched as they were with that 8-bit midi style the game tries to make its own. And even the navigation is empty and lazy you essentially no-clip with gravity the whole time. You will never feel as though you are walking or are an entity at all except when creatures run from you and weather you are swimming, going up or down hill, or running in a grotto your speed will not change.This lazy half an hour (at best) experience feels as though the developer is screaming at me to appriciate thier work and I feel I could if I weren't asked to cough up 10 bucks for it when games like Cloud are being offered for free by other developers. If you are looking to take some pretty screenshots to make some nice 8-bit wallpapers then maybe this is for you. If you are looking to kick back and relax in an exploratory game then I can definitely recommend something better with a cheaper price tag if not for free.

Posted: May 31, 2013
												Proteus isn't a game, so if you're looking for levels and story, back off now. Proteus is a trip. 												More than once I've heard "at least Minecraft is more interactive." Yes, that's true. There's no TNT or redstone or swords or enchantments or endermen here. This game is not for everyone. And that's fine. Don't buy it if the above paragraph doesn't sound appealing, because this game is simply not for you. Posted: January 26, 2014
												Alright, if you thought Gone Home "wasn't a game" because it didn't involve shooting dudes in the face well you really won't like this one.  Proteus puts you on a procedurally-generated island, with graphics that will show off the horsepower of your new 386.   It's a vacation to a magic land of pixelated trees and wildlife, where fireflies dance in the woods at night and a circle of mysterious stones can take you to the next season - spring, summer, fall and winter all have different characters.  There's an ending of sorts, but the entire game is calm, slow, plotless, but graphically stunning in its low-resolution way. Certain vistas made me gasp or smile when I moved through them.  The music is also procedural, setting ambient electronic mood that matches perfectly with the visuals.  I like to just run it in the background to play the music.Proteus is digital antidepressant and well worth experiencing from time to time when you need to destress.NOTE: On Mac OS X, it took over a minute of black screen at the beginning before it came up - just be advised to wait without any kind of feedback before the title screen.  I had thought it had crashed several times before I waited.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												ProteusProteus is a very interesting piece of work. I don’t call it a game because it doesn’t fit into that category in any traditional sense. It’s less of a game and more of an experiment in musical exploration. After giving it a try for a few hours and seeing a bit of what it offers, I feel confident giving it a solid recommendation for those of you who are looking for something a little different. Allow me to explain why, and perhaps snag your interest.Proteus begins simply; you open your eyes. You find yourself standing waist deep in the ocean, and can just make out an island off in the distance in front of you. Naturally, you will make your way towards it. Upon reaching the island, it becomes clear that there are some key differences between Proteus and other games. For starters, there is no music until you reach the island. Once you arrive and the music starts to play, you are in for a treat. It is all generated procedurally by what is around you. Frogs, toads, birds and even flowers all play their own notes as you move around and interact with each of them. These sounds combine to form very relaxing musical numbers. The soundtrack, as a result, is a fascinating part of the game. It is in part created by you, the player, and thus becomes a form of gameplay by itself. It’s a brilliant idea put into great use by the developers.So how about the rest of the gameplay then? It’s equally strange. Upon setting foot on the island, you are left entirely to your own devices. At no point do you ever see text, receive an objective, or have a designated goal handed to you. You are entirely on your own. And that’s exactly how it should be. Explore, find hidden little secrets and tidbits and write your own story! When you are prepared to quit, you don’t simply press escape and use a menu to quit. Instead you hold down the escape key, and your eyes begin to close. Quitting is represented as returning to sleep. When you’re ready to play again, you once more open your eyes and find yourself standing waist deep in water, with an entirely new, procedurally generated island waiting for you in the distance. Each new game is a new day, a new world, and a new opportunity for discovery.I personally came away from Proteus filled with wonder, and far more relaxed than when I went in. It is almost meditative rather than being tense and stressful. For anyone with an open mind looking to try something new, Proteus is a fantastic and beautiful way to relax and pass the time. There’s nothing else quite like it on the market. The most closely related comparison would come from last year’s Playstation 3 exclusive title, Journey, by ThatGameCompany, and that is a glowing comparison to a fantastic game. Proteus is a great little title in a sea of big-budget blockbusters, and should not be overlooked. Give it a shot, you may find yourself pleasantly surprised.

Posted: February 2, 2014
												I am very conflicted by this game. There are really, a lot of redeaming qualities, and I often do like exploration based gameplay, it's just that there's not a lot to see here.What there is to see is nice. I love the art direction, the world is just flat out breathtaking. So much life is made through a very simple "8-bit-esc" art style. Despite there being not much life on the island (there is some), it just feels very full and vibrant. The sound design tops the visuals though with just a beautiful "8-bit-esc" ambiance and sound effects. The problem I have with suggesting this game though is that not everyone in the world is a fan of what is essentially virtual tourism. You see great sights and hear very pleasent noises, but that's it. If anything, it is more like a painting with a soundtrack which you can walk through, which is not an inheriently bad idea. I would feel better about this game if there was more honestly, but despite random generation of the island, it doesn't offer much variety. Luckily I got it for $2, which feels like the perfect price to me.But for the $10 price, I would not reccomend it. While I'm sure the creator worked hard on the game, there is not enough content to warrent the price tag. But hey, it's better than Dear Esther. I personally enjoyed Proteus for what it was but I just can't tell you to go buy it.

Back when it was a far simpler game. Vivid thoughts of me wading out of the water to a small peninsula to start building a shelter, Those scary nights hearing the growls and hisses of the mobs as I hid in my underground dwelling. Than meekly venturing out during the day; scaling a small hill by my house, assuming I was only on an island and expecting to see the shoreline, than being confronting by endless lands. Its that lasting realization that your a small thing a large, large world that sticks with you.Proteus is exactly like that, little moments of things and occurances you merely stumble upon that accumulate into something you'll is instilled into your memory and stay with you.

Posted: May 17, 2014
												I had just finished a stressful match of League of Legends and I decided that I needed to take a breather, so I loaded up Steam and remembered I had just bought this game as apart of a Humble Bundle. Figuring that it could be good, I installed it, put on my headphones, and dove in. Waking up waist deep in the pixelated ocean, I was immersed in a simple yet utterly beautiful world. I watched day turn to night and night turn to day. There were no goals, nor any rules of what I had to do. I walked around an island, listening to the world. I climbed a mountain and heard the sea wind blowing. I walked into the rain and heard a gentle drizzle land on the nearby trees. As I played-- no, not played. As I experienced Proteus, I felt my muscles relieve themselves, and even now do I feel utterly calm. I can't explain this game, because it's not a game. Walking through Proteus was a reminder that the world is beautiful, and all we have to do is take time to see it.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												This game's very design--from the curious yet delightful sounds, soft and pleasant colors, and soul-quelling music, to the way the player's screen enters and exits the game like eyes slowly opening and closing--is meant to be strongly reminiscent of a dream; a beautiful, subjective dream. A dream where the more you get lost within, the more you get lost within your own thoughts. Abandon the day-to-day burdens of goals, duties, tasks, competition, opposition, and reward--the values that our workaholic, robotic, and disconnected society holds so dear. Abandon those--just for a few moments, and take the time to bask yourself into consciousness within another plane. Take the time to simply... be.

												Proteus is, in my opinion, the most beautiful game I have ever played. It's a quiet game about exploring and experiencing an unknown world. In this world, you are rewarded for your curiosity--but not in the "bonus points" and "level up" sort of reward. Instead, your reward for what you discover is the very witnessing of what you've uncovered. The world is fully immersive if you let it be--immaculately gorgeous and warmly sonorous. Proteus is a game that asks for your wonder. If you give it, you will experience something both comfortably familiar and excitingly new.

Posted: January 26, 2014
												Alright, if you thought Gone Home "wasn't a game" because it didn't involve shooting dudes in the face well you really won't like this one.  Proteus puts you on a procedurally-generated island, with graphics that will show off the horsepower of your new 386.   It's a vacation to a magic land of pixelated trees and wildlife, where fireflies dance in the woods at night and a circle of mysterious stones can take you to the next season - spring, summer, fall and winter all have different characters.  There's an ending of sorts, but the entire game is calm, slow, plotless, but graphically stunning in its low-resolution way. Certain vistas made me gasp or smile when I moved through them.  The music is also procedural, setting ambient electronic mood that matches perfectly with the visuals.  I like to just run it in the background to play the music.Proteus is digital antidepressant and well worth experiencing from time to time when you need to destress.NOTE: On Mac OS X, it took over a minute of black screen at the beginning before it came up - just be advised to wait without any kind of feedback before the title screen.  I had thought it had crashed several times before I waited.

Posted: August 27, 2015
												The boundaries between what is a "game" and "art" are being more blurred, or revealed not to actually exist, more and more, and Proteus is a clear example of this. Clearly if you are solely into "traditional" game structure you will not really enjoy your experience because you will be trying to achieve something or wondering if you "beat" it. The game isn't going to give you that feedback; it won't pat you on the back or give you an achievement for interacting with a new creature or playing through multiple times because that is not the point of this game. The "point" is whatever the you want it to be; you are playing solely because you want to, there are not really many ulterior motives. The game creates an immersive atmosphere through visuals, audio, and minimal interactive elements, and it is up to you what you do with that. If you don't like it, don't play it. If you do, keep enjoying and exploring.I understand that this is an extremely polarizing game, but one thing that many people who negatively review it are missing is that they claim to have "completed" the game in 30 minutes, and are disappointed about not getting their "bang for their buck." But the problem is you can't "complete" Proteus. There is no built in goals or achievements.  Experiencing one cycle does not constitute anything really in terms of objective progress; everything you gain from your playtime is subjective, it is up to you what you gain (or if you gain anything) from your playtime.I'll admit $10 may be a bit pricy for this title, however it is entirely your decision to buy this and enough is known and has said about this game where you know what you're getting into if you are purchasing it. I personally loved the couple run throughs I have experienced and definitely plan on revisiting Proteus periodically. For me it is a beautiful little escape where everything is familiar yet new, and in just 30 minutes I am given a feeling of catharsis that I may not even be able to understand, but it feels beautiful every time.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												ProteusProteus is a very interesting piece of work. I don’t call it a game because it doesn’t fit into that category in any traditional sense. It’s less of a game and more of an experiment in musical exploration. After giving it a try for a few hours and seeing a bit of what it offers, I feel confident giving it a solid recommendation for those of you who are looking for something a little different. Allow me to explain why, and perhaps snag your interest.Proteus begins simply; you open your eyes. You find yourself standing waist deep in the ocean, and can just make out an island off in the distance in front of you. Naturally, you will make your way towards it. Upon reaching the island, it becomes clear that there are some key differences between Proteus and other games. For starters, there is no music until you reach the island. Once you arrive and the music starts to play, you are in for a treat. It is all generated procedurally by what is around you. Frogs, toads, birds and even flowers all play their own notes as you move around and interact with each of them. These sounds combine to form very relaxing musical numbers. The soundtrack, as a result, is a fascinating part of the game. It is in part created by you, the player, and thus becomes a form of gameplay by itself. It’s a brilliant idea put into great use by the developers.So how about the rest of the gameplay then? It’s equally strange. Upon setting foot on the island, you are left entirely to your own devices. At no point do you ever see text, receive an objective, or have a designated goal handed to you. You are entirely on your own. And that’s exactly how it should be. Explore, find hidden little secrets and tidbits and write your own story! When you are prepared to quit, you don’t simply press escape and use a menu to quit. Instead you hold down the escape key, and your eyes begin to close. Quitting is represented as returning to sleep. When you’re ready to play again, you once more open your eyes and find yourself standing waist deep in water, with an entirely new, procedurally generated island waiting for you in the distance. Each new game is a new day, a new world, and a new opportunity for discovery.I personally came away from Proteus filled with wonder, and far more relaxed than when I went in. It is almost meditative rather than being tense and stressful. For anyone with an open mind looking to try something new, Proteus is a fantastic and beautiful way to relax and pass the time. There’s nothing else quite like it on the market. The most closely related comparison would come from last year’s Playstation 3 exclusive title, Journey, by ThatGameCompany, and that is a glowing comparison to a fantastic game. Proteus is a great little title in a sea of big-budget blockbusters, and should not be overlooked. Give it a shot, you may find yourself pleasantly surprised.

The sound design tops the visuals though with just a beautiful "8-bit-esc" ambiance and sound effects. The problem I have with suggesting this game though is that not everyone in the world is a fan of what is essentially virtual tourism. You see great sights and hear very pleasent noises, but that's it. If anything, it is more like a painting with a soundtrack which you can walk through, which is not an inheriently bad idea. Posted: January 6, 2014
												Amazing. Absolutely fantastic. It's relaxing, it's beautiful, and it made me smile with glee on more than one occasion. The music is wonderfully done, and the way every single thing in the area changes it makes it amazing and so it never gets boring. There are small creatures to interact with, that are cute  and have sound that meshes so perfectly with the music from your surroundings, and it's nice to have something that doesn't involve killing and that has no dark storyline. Overall just a fantastic game.

Posted: January 6, 2014
												Proteus isn't a "game" as noted in many other reviews. It's an exploration through 4 seasons on a procedurally generated island. While this in itself isn't a bad thing, there simply isn't enough to see to justify buying it. If it were an early access game or some sort of tech demo or something, I'd say give it a shot if you're bored. But your money would be much better spent on another game. If you want to do some exploring, go down to a local park. There'll be much more to see than Proteus has to offer.

Posted: January 6, 2014
												Given that I paid $2 on a Daily Deal, I'll give this one a thumbs up.   It could be said that it's far more "activity" than "game"; and at about 45 minutes for a run through, I would likely haven felt quite a bit different if I'd paid $10 for it.   That said, it is unique and creative. I probably wouldn't give this game another 45 minutes of my time and by comparison, I found Dear Esther, similar yet superior in pretty much every way.

Posted: April 2, 2013
												Proteus is the most casual and relaxing game I've ever experienced. The sound track is tailored to your experience and what is happening in the world around you making it pleasing to listen to. The art style is fun to admire and if you play through enough times you'll experience many new creatures, objects, and events throughout the island. However, it isn't worth $10 to me due to the small amount of hours I found myself investing in it. If you want a unique game bound to soothe the soul, go for it. Definitely grab it if it goes on sale.

Posted: July 29, 2014
												My initial opinion of this game was that it is boring and pointless... actually, that's still my opinion of the game. The experience is more like an interactive screensaver. There are no action buttons, no sprinting, no jumping and no death. You simply walk around and enjoy the ambience. There are no goals or objectives other than the ones you set for yourself. Even those were simple tasks such as, make it to the top of that mountain, chase the squirrel, or try to find that tree that played bagpipes. I owe my positive opinion of the game to a gameplay review that I was attempting to record. After several takes, the environment started to grow on me. It was amazing how long I found myself wandering around while still trying to make myself hate it. This is not for everyone, but I see the appeal now. While this is not a must buy or must play, the experience is unique and enjoyable.

Posted: July 16, 2014
												A beautiful game that doesn't offer a single objective. I recommend buying it on sale. The replay value is rather low despite the randomly generated islands.

Posted: January 17, 2014
												This isn't a game for everyone.And you'll know right off the bat whether you'll like it or not.Consider this game to be a holiday location in the video game realm, it is a place where the digital generation can unwind after a hard day's work killing zombies and setting up trade routes across the galaxy.A pure, filtering of the basic exploration and discovery mechanic, and everything else has been stripped out.Wait for everyone to go to bed, hole up in your room, turn out the lights and turn off the internet, put on your headphones, and explore the island that's been willed into existence just for you. The first five minutes might seem a bit odd, you'll be expecting something to attack you, or  for some puzzle to bar your way to the next area, but when you understand that this is a safe and free place for you, you will understand that we live in a beautiful world, and that it is yours to explore and experience.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												I picked this gem up in a Humble Bundle a ways back and have enjoyed it from time to time. When you open the game it puts you into a procedually generated island so it's a unique experience each time and I still find something new almost everytime that I play it. I is verry calming and has an unexpected " Ending " to it. I love this game and just being able to come in and relax exploring the island is a great thing. I can say that this is not a game for everybody and you should think about buying it before you invest in it.

Posted: August 27, 2014
												This is an incredible experience.I am not usually one for things billed as "relaxation".  I literally cannot count to ten for the purpose of relaxing my mind; the attempt triggers very unpleasant memories for me, which I guess I won't go into here.  I regard essentially everything - nature audio recordings, massage, etc - billed on those merits with extreme skepticism.Proteus is in a different league.  A true meditative experience.  Also a rumination on aloneness and what it means, which is very close to the core thing I need to come to terms with in my own life, so it's really wonderful to play.The visuals are already really beautiful, but the audio takes it above and beyond.  I played around with it for about half an hour and found a bunch of stuff, but not everything, according to the forums.  I'll probably go back another day - this is strong stuff, and I can't do too much at once! - but it would have easily been worth the $10 even for the one session.Thank you.

Posted: September 6, 2014
												Proteus is art, but it is not a game. If you like the concept of intrigue and immersion while walking around a funny little island, then get this game.That being said, if you're looking for a point, steer clear because there is none. All you do is walk around looking at trees, creatures, and monoliths. There isn't an ending, and it doesn't really qualify as a game. It's artsy, so if you're like me and you're looking for direction or things to do, you don't want this kind of limited experience.I recommend it because while I didn't particularly gel with the purpose of Proteus, I can appreciate the purpose and the time spent creating it; hell, each island is randomly generated which has gotta be worth something. That said, though, 10 bucks is a bit much. If the price drops to say, 5 dollars, or less, I would say give it a try. 5 bucks is the price of a hamburger. Really not a total loss, even if you didn't fully enjoy the game.

Posted: March 25, 2014
												This game is technically interesting, and worth an hour of your time, but little more.  In Proteus you find yoruself on an island and are never given any objective, though at verious points you discover "events" which are obviously your progression to the next section of the game.  The game is very relaxing, and the art is peculiar but also pleaseing.  ITs a work of art, but, unless you can play an almost aimless game and enjoy exploring, you probably won't understand this games appeal.  If its cheap, or if your a fan of "art as a game", this is a great experiance, if only to broader your horizens and if you happen to enjoy it, you'll find a great escape when you need to relax and forget about life for awhile.

Posted: March 26, 2014
												Initially pretty interesting. Played again and well it was the same island, with the same sounds and creatures. Interesting sounds coupled with minimalist graphics - pretty, but pretty boring overall.It feels like an interesting experiment, but you won't find yourself coming back for more. It seems to boast of it's infinite amounts to explore, but every time you restart you have to go through days worth (not literal, but game days) of the same stuff you've already seen and experienced. On top of that, the new stuff is just not really that exciting.I did enjoy it for a little bit - had some wine and kicked back. However, to recommend this "game" for the asking price I simply can't do. Great expirement, but and overall boring experience. I'd be very eager to see future experiments by these game designers, but can't recommend this piece.

Posted: May 3, 2014
												While it's not as satisfying as, say, Flower or Journey, Proteus is a relaxing, very short exploration game-as-Art that is competently done and has some really good audio design behind it.  It maybe isn't anything revolutionary, but you can tell a fair amount of care and exploratory experience (if that makes sense) went into it.  In fact, I wish there was a "screensaver" or self-playing mode, because I feel like it would be neat to experience it more (or in the background), but I don't particularly feel that I need to physically play it again.  Just make sure you know what to expect by checking a few minutes of an LP to make sure the gameplay and "lo-fi" graphics aren't a personal turn-off, and pick it up in a bundle or really good sale.Supposedly there is a soundtrack version planned, something that would've increased the value substantially in my opinion.  I've also read rumors about Oculus Rift support, which would be a small plus (though not a big one as the graphics are rather flat, and there's often a lot of fog).  I was somewhat skeptical before, but now I'll keep my ears open for the developer's and composer's next projects.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												This game reminds me of a time in my teens, going to the fair and paying money to peek in a majestic aquarium and see a mermaid. I don't know what I actually thought I'd see, probably nothing amazing, but it ended up being a really ugly old fat man in a one piece bathing suit and an XXL long sleeve green tshirt around "her" legs, sitting at the bottom of a disguised dunk tank. I paid one dollar and fifty cents to see that man and this game disappointed me more. Its exactly what you'd expect, except with less going on. It's peaceful, but if that's what you're into, hiking in real life is free at a lot of places and the rabbits are more than 4 pixels. It was the anticipation that made me hate it, if I just stumbled across this for free, coded into a web page, I'd probably play for five minutes and then stop and be like, "Hey, that was sort of cool."You can press Q, and it auto-walks forward, and you just look around with the mouse with really not much other than trees to see, aside from a few graves, and the changing time of day. I think a lot of people are arguing that this is art, or this game is just trying to be different and show that you don't need goals or objectives, but from my perspective, many of those people are just fighting the norm, playing the devil's advocate. I can't see someone spending more than 20 minutes max on this game.Overall: 2/10 for being pretty.

Posted: June 4, 2013
												I believe games can be art but not all art can be games.  Proteus is not a game.  It is an auditory and visual experience with virtually no interaction.  Truthfully, I think if Proteus had an semblance of gameplay it could be quite unique and worth playing.  "Flower" on the PS3, for example, is art but also has simple gameplay and leaves a lasting impression.  Proteus has none of this.  Fortunately, it was free in the a Humble Bundle. 1/5 Stars

Posted: June 27, 2014
												It is incorrect to say this is not a game and more like an interactive experience. Yes it is an interactive experience, all games are interactive experiences, but this is indeed a game. Those that claim it is not a game just haven’t spent the time figuring out the mechanics of the game or taken the time to search for guides online. You can choose to explore aimlessly and enjoy the peacfulness of the world or you can follow a set of rules in order to experience the timeline of the game and end (or beat) the game. Unless you create a snapshot, everytime you play the game you will be in a newly generated world. So even if you've finished the game before, you can try again in a new world.

Posted: July 23, 2014
												So.....I have mixed feelings about this game. Did I enjoy playing through it once? Yes.Will I ever touch it or even install it again? Not likely. Essentially, all you do is wander aimlessly through a procedurally generated island. The island has a day/night cycle, and seasons. There are a small variety of animals that make various musical sounds as they move.That's pretty much this whole game. Now, there are lots of good things to be said about it. It was certainly interesting, and I think that an attempt to be creative and make a new type of game is admirable and overall a good thing. However, I feel the same way about this game that I do about those random splotch paintings in art museums - I look at it, and think, "that's interesting" and then leave it, feeling like I should have gleaned something more from the experience, but not really sure what exactly that should have been.The reason I don't recommend this game is mostly because I think it is extremely overpriced. There is maybe 1 or 2 dollars worth of game here. If it's on sale for about that much, it's probably worth giving a shot, just for the experience. But 10 dollars is way, way too much for this game. If you want to spend that much, go for it. Just remember you're buying one of those random splotch paintings.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												Proteus is a game by Ed Key and David Kanaga which has received nominations; awards; mixed reviews from various sites and bloggers; and challenged the notion of what a game is. This game is on the border between video games and art and so you could call it an ‘Art Game’.Whether you think Proteus is worth the $10 that’s being asked depends on what you’re after. As a game, I would say $10 is not worth it. But if you’re after a simple, well-designed and eloquent piece of interactive art, then this is for you, especially considering that you can buy non-interactive, static, noiseless posters of your favourite movie for around $15.For full review, visit:http://icarusreviews.net/2013/05/06/brief-write-of-a-brief-flight-proteus/

												This game really helps out when i'm having a bad day. It lets me just relax and feel at peace. Don't buy it expecting a game, buy it expecting a rejuvenating experience.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Proteus is sort of an open-world exploration game in a cute pastel, pixely environment. While there is a goal, you'll probably discover it accidentally and understand what to do, but for me the main enjoyment of the game comes from getting to know the landscape and its inhabitants. There are stylistic versions of chickens, frogs, and other animals that make me grin when I see them. The weather changes, from a sunny day to rainy even to nighttime.Overall, it's a wonderful game to play when you're stressed and need relaxation, or just need to unwind in general. It's a great game for just slowing things down, and the music is wonderful as well.The only problem that I have with the game is that my computer won't run the full version (not sure why--it's a decent computer), so I have to play one of the beta versions on Steam. I have played the full version offline on other computers.To me, this isn't one of those games that I just sit down and play anytime (it's usually when I want to de-stress), but it's well worth it to buy. I'd give it an 8/10, but you should only buy it if you're interested in this sort of game.

Posted: January 19, 2014
												Proteus is an excellent "game" if you can call it that to relax you. With its peaceful soundtrack and beautiful world roaming the island will be the most peaceful 40 minutes you can possibly have. After finishing Proteus for the first time it can be rewarding to play through it again due to the island being different every time. All in all Proteus isn't for everyone since there are no objectives however after one plays a heavy session of a hardcore game one can relax with Proteus. Recommended

Posted: January 19, 2014
												Proteus is a pixelated, first-person adventure game where you explore the island of Proteus and interact with its inhabitants. The artwork, sounds, and music are very good for the most part, and the first half of the game makes you curious and intrigued as to what different sights there are to see on the island and how to interact with different things that you find (as the game offers no instructions or tutorial, but instead lets you find out how to play and explore Proteus on your own.)The second half of the game, however, is very dull and boring, and these negative aspects worsen until the game finishes. Also, after 1 or 2 playthroughs, you've pretty much seen everything, as Protues is a very short title that should take less than an hour to complete, and there's no incentive to play again. In fact, the painfully dull second half of the game may DETER players from exploring Proteus again.In short, the first half of Proteus is quite well done, but considering the boring second half and lack of replay value, the positive qualities of this game are not enough to recommend a purchase.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												Let's get one thing straight from the beginning - Proteus isn't a game. It's an experience. It combines two elements - sound and vision - to create a uniquely moving and personal experience as you roam a small island. You don't do anything. You explore your own personal world, one that teems with surprises. You won't forget the first time you walk through a creaking forest at night and an owl hoots at you form a nearby tree. Nor will you forget the first time you stepped atop a mountain. The first sunrise actually set the hairs on my arms on end.It's about exploring what Proteus has to offer with your eyes and ears. Both sounds and sights are simultaneously abstract and magnificent, drawing the traveller deeper in. You could find yourself chasing a bunny for the strong notes it creates versus a melodic background, or simply sitting under a tree watching a sunset, admiring the view and ambience.As I said, Proteus is an experience - if you don't give it the time it deserves, you won't feel it as you should, you won't be drawn in as the developers intended. If you want instant gratification, go play CoD. But if you want something a little deeper, a little more personal, something that isn't all about the numbers, give Proteus a try.Starman

Posted: January 11, 2014
												Proteus makes Dear Esther look like GTAV. I know sometimes developers read these reviews, and I don't like to be cruel. So please forgive me, devs, if you read this. Proteus is a horrible piece of pretentious garbage. It was given to me as a gift, so I gave it a try. After 20 minutes I am totally and completely finished, and I have absolutely no idea what I am meant to get out of this. Proteus is about wandering a pastel day-glo island where NOTHING HAPPENS. You can walk into obelisks (oh boy) and you'll get teleported to other parts of the island. Sometimes animals will scurry out of your way. Once in a while glowing lights will form into a circle and you can stand in it, and then it goes from night to day. Hold on to your hats, people!Maybe I'm missing something. Maybe I'm not appreciating the subtle, inexorable beauty of this minimalist enterprise. Maybe I'm bringing faulty hard-hearted expectations from console shoot-em-ups into something which is clearly trying to tread a different path, one of intangible essences and abstract textures. Maybe I'm going to puke all over my keyboard.While I appreciate everyone who tries something different, that does not automatically qualify their products for a badge of quality, fun, or beauty. In this case I have experienced none of those. Just a boring romp around a boring island.I feel like 20 precious minutes of my life have been wasted, and I want them back. Stay away!
