Posted: September 13, 2014
												I will warn you now: Proteus is not for everyone.There are those who won't see the beauty behind the pixels. They are not wrong, they are not bad. They just have a different view.There are those who will be touched by the intrigue. They feel immersion, curiosity. I hope that you can be counted in these numbers.Proteus has no point. No goal. No villain. No ultimate evil that needs to be stopped. It simply has time. You can spend as much or as little time as you want just being. You may see many things that you have seen before. You may see a few things that you will never see again. And that is all that is asked of you. See, observe, explore.I personally played Proteus because I liked the idea that it posed. What I came away with was a lot more than the beauty of the idea. I came away feeling sad, because of what I had seen and what I had been powerless to stop. I came away feeling happy, because of the beauty in what I had seen and the fact that I had no power over it.Never have I felt like I do now. Proteus is an experience that is not quite like anything else. I have no real comparison to it. Buy it, play it through. If you're like me, you'll understand why I love it so much.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												I accidentally bought this game and thought hell i may as well install it and try it now. I've never ever been more pleasantly suprised by a mistake.I would recommend Proteus but i need to stress, not as a game and to be honest, i didn't play it thinking that. Within the first 60 seconds i could tell that this wasn't a game in the traditional sense. As i piece of art i would heavily recommend it. I would more so like to recommend it to people looking for some sort of tool to induce calm.It's "gameplay" is a simple 3d based movement mechanic without sprinting of jumping functions. So far all i've done is wander around and be constantly suprised by little quirks. I love the sounds of this game so much, from its little animals to the random gusts of wind. I had no expectations and i've enjoyed it. If you're looking for...well a video game, i'd say steer clear of this title. If however you want to try something different then i'd whole heartedly recommend it. I hope you enjoy it.I use it as a calming tool and it really does work. No guides, no enemies, no objectives, no worries.

Posted: March 20, 2013
												Proteus is an experience, plain and simple.  It's a game that's hard to categorize but no less compelling because of it.  The charm it exudes as you wander through it's fantastical world cannot be denied, and as it grows on you, it opens up a part of you that you may have thought was lost from your childhood.  The world of Proteus is a musical one, and a living one.  The world reacts to you and sings to you as you explore it.  As the symphonies of rain drops and rustling trees combine, they start to make sense and melt together with the vibrant scenery into something beautiful and beyond description.  Proteus is a work of art, a tool for relaxation, a vibrant and ever-changing chorus, and so many other things that it feels futile to try to describe the sum of its part.  Simply put, the only thing you can do is play the game for yourself, and let it amaze you.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												Back in the mid-90s I used to spend a little time in a "virtual reality" chat program called Alphaworld, which I suppose was a sort of early Second Life, but I rarely ever wanted to talk to people, instead preferring to wander around and look at creations and just explore. A few minutes of "playing" Proteus gave me exactly that feeling again; a sort of lazy and relaxed exploration that's enhanced by the otherworldly music you help create by walking through or near objects.I found myself just spotting something in the distance and lazily wandering in that direction, idly coming up with a theory and then meandering off to some other interesting thing I saw on another hill. I'd love to see what this game would be like with something like the Oculus Rift; I expect it'd be wonderfully immersive and relaxing!I'm recommending because I found it a beautiful, stress-relieving and thorougly relaxing experience that reminded me of something I used to do that I'd almost forgotten about. It's not something I'd "play" for hours, but a half-hour or so or meandering through beautiful, surreal scenary once in a while sounds great. Glad I picked Proteus up!

												There's something wonderfully meditative about Proteus. Posted: August 10, 2014
												I began my journey not knowing what to expect. I awoke in an 8 bit world. I was about to have a first person atari style adventure. I was in the middle of what appeared to be a vast ocean. It was very foggy, but I could see land in the distance. I could also see a comforting and familiar sun. I choose to head towards land. Gameplay wise, there isn't much there. wasd to move and you can also look around. Initially I was annoyed at the slow pace and the fact that once I had arrived at a castle like building I could not enter. My curiousity to learn more drove me to continue my journey. There were interesting sounds and visions all around. I appeared to be on an island inhibited by many creatures and containing it's own weather system. Soon enough the clouds began to disperse and the sun began to set. With night upon me I enjoyed some light star gazing upon a snowy mountain top. I noted the slow movement of the stars. Once again my emotions switched when I came to a small cottage down the mountain side following a dirt path. Not only could I not enter this cottage, but the door itself looked terrible. I would not be fooled....no one lives here. No one has for some time.....I started my next day much like the first, blindy moving forward in an effort to discover what, if anything, remains to be discovered. This is where I had my first encounter. A silly creature bounced gracefully away from me. It did not matter how I decided to approach, the creature was sure to make haste. Remnicient of Stan's dad in South Park attempting to "catch the Dragon" I gave chase to this creature. I followed it so long that eventually we arrived at the shore line. Sadly the creature simply hopped into the water, never to be seen again. I happened upon numerous more of these creatures during my team on the island. My experience remained the same. I would follow until I could no longer. Eventually I found a circle of what appeared to be grave stones. Upon bumping into one I noticed a small "bend" in reality. The world in which I was located was being distorted by these things. Whilst looking around  I realized the pace of this world changing picking up. Soon I was watching as days were flying by before my eyes. Getting a grip on my bewilderment I became aware of the small circle in the center of these stones, seemingly created by wind. It seemed to call me. Feeling as though it was my destiny I entered the circle.Opening my eyes once again I took note of a slightly new sun. Perhaps this was a new world, or perhaps I had simply traveled through time. The landscape had changed. The entire pace of things seemed to pick up entirely. Wildlife was much more abundant than the when or where from which I had traveled. I had received exactly what I had asked for, as if I had somehow  directed the growth of this existence. After taking in what this new landscape had to offer I once again happened upon the bounding bouncing creature from before. Only this time something was different. The creature appeared to have let me get ever so slightly closer before making it's escape. I'm not sure what will happen to me now. I feel as though my only route is forward. It is as if I have put a curse on myself to make a goal of understanding this creature. I fear I may never catch it, but I also feel that I must try. It occurs to me that I may travel endless worlds in search of my goal, wandering through time and space relentlessy. It is for that reason that I leave this record of my travels. Perhaps as a warning, perhaps as an explanation. If this is to be my last correspondence, please hope for me. Hope that I have attained my goal of capturing the bouncing creature. ------I would definitely define this as an exploration or art type game. It is a soothing experience that may help certain people feel calm or tap into the childlike wonder of days long past many of us have forgotten. Recommended For: Anyone with a tramatic past"City-folk" who will never see real starsIndividuals afraid to leave their homesAnyone who is really stoned.Not Recommended for: Graphics ♥♥♥♥♥sFast paced action junkiesMeth addicts. Recommended, but only under specific conditions. I honestly would probably be upset if I had paid much for this game.

												A slow paced walking simulator that is more bland and confusing than Dear Esther. The game was neat through my first playthrough, but it wasn't really rewarding. Posted: September 6, 2014
												Proteus is art, but it is not a game. If you like the concept of intrigue and immersion while walking around a funny little island, then get this game.That being said, if you're looking for a point, steer clear because there is none. All you do is walk around looking at trees, creatures, and monoliths. There isn't an ending, and it doesn't really qualify as a game. It's artsy, so if you're like me and you're looking for direction or things to do, you don't want this kind of limited experience.I recommend it because while I didn't particularly gel with the purpose of Proteus, I can appreciate the purpose and the time spent creating it; hell, each island is randomly generated which has gotta be worth something. That said, though, 10 bucks is a bit much. If the price drops to say, 5 dollars, or less, I would say give it a try. 5 bucks is the price of a hamburger. Really not a total loss, even if you didn't fully enjoy the game.

Posted: June 4, 2013
												I'd hesitate to call this a game, but it's interesting nonetheless. You get a randomly generated island with pixelly 3D graphics, and the music can be changed just by walking around and exploring.  There's a magic circle that changes the season when you approach it at night, and season affects both your audio experience and your video experience.With its postcard feature, you can take a screenshot that has your randomly generated world encoded into it, and send it to a friend, who can then load your world and explore it themselves.As for whether it's worth buying, it's hit or miss.  This might be the kind of thing you like, or it might not.  Grab it on sale if you can.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												I got this on sale for $2.  While I wouldn't have spent $10 on it, there's no remorse in purchasing this game for less than the cost of a large bag of chips.  It's also about 90MB, which meant it was playable within minutes, and isn't taking up a huge amount of space on my machine.  I can keep it there and come back to it from time to time with no guilt.Now, from someone who DID NOT enjoy Dear Esther, I do like this.  It's fun to just walk around.  Laugh because I made the little square bees angry, or something.  Unlike Dear Esther, which has lofty, pretentious aims, this is just there to let you relax, and doesn't pretend to be anything more.  It's the squishy stress ball of games.  At no point will you be stuck on x area, looking for some stupid bauble, or trying to get the game to trigger an event by doing the right hoohah dance, or whatever.  Grab it while it's $2, and play it when you're too stressed to even handle conventional game play.  (You KNOW that happens.)

Posted: June 5, 2013
												I've always been a sucker for games like these. At first I wondered if the 9 euros I put down was a mistake. After my first playthrough at around 45 minutes, I was absolutely positive that not a single cent was wasted.Really, it's like walking around in a dream with lo-fi graphics.The game is very simple, both in concept and graphics. It's a game I will play from time to time, to relax, or to just be amazed for an hour or so. There's always something new to see, and it's always just as intoxicating.I recommend you buy Proteus and support the hard-working developers. It's one of the most charming walks in recent memory.

Posted: August 25, 2013
												who signed off on this? this is the type of game you show to your uncle after your  aunt (his wife) has just passed away. although the funeral isn't till thursday, he insists on staying over three nights prior (monday), and just by consequence of his very existence, you become desperate to show your extracurricular activities are not damaging. "what exactly is this?", he asks between sobs. you slide the headphones over his ears. "why it's a procedurally-generated landscape of terrible textures and audio trigger points, that lacks any intrigue, and in which nothing at all happens." he sighs, plays it for FIVE freakin' hours. you sleep downstairs with the un-killable cat; cursing the plan, the game, your aunt (his wife), the whole world.post: i would like to add that the concept is a lovely one, it's just the execution that is lacking. i feel as though an experience like this should have some semblance of longetivity. for me at least, it didn't. one set of rolling hills blended into the other and any sense of discovery soon disappeared.

Posted: July 23, 2014
												So.....I have mixed feelings about this game. Did I enjoy playing through it once? Yes.Will I ever touch it or even install it again? Not likely. Essentially, all you do is wander aimlessly through a procedurally generated island. The island has a day/night cycle, and seasons. There are a small variety of animals that make various musical sounds as they move.That's pretty much this whole game. Now, there are lots of good things to be said about it. It was certainly interesting, and I think that an attempt to be creative and make a new type of game is admirable and overall a good thing. However, I feel the same way about this game that I do about those random splotch paintings in art museums - I look at it, and think, "that's interesting" and then leave it, feeling like I should have gleaned something more from the experience, but not really sure what exactly that should have been.The reason I don't recommend this game is mostly because I think it is extremely overpriced. There is maybe 1 or 2 dollars worth of game here. If it's on sale for about that much, it's probably worth giving a shot, just for the experience. But 10 dollars is way, way too much for this game. If you want to spend that much, go for it. Just remember you're buying one of those random splotch paintings.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												Proteus is a game by Ed Key and David Kanaga which has received nominations; awards; mixed reviews from various sites and bloggers; and challenged the notion of what a game is. This game is on the border between video games and art and so you could call it an ‘Art Game’.Whether you think Proteus is worth the $10 that’s being asked depends on what you’re after. As a game, I would say $10 is not worth it. But if you’re after a simple, well-designed and eloquent piece of interactive art, then this is for you, especially considering that you can buy non-interactive, static, noiseless posters of your favourite movie for around $15.For full review, visit:http://icarusreviews.net/2013/05/06/brief-write-of-a-brief-flight-proteus/

Posted: January 7, 2014
												The game involves wandering around an island.  That's it.  The graphics are very crude, the only stand out feature is the audio.  The clever idea is that everything in the visual landscape reflects itself in an audio landscape that you wander through at the same time.  As the weather and the seasons change the music reflects in this.  Blooming trees lead to resonant earthy sounds,  wondering past gravestones leads to ominous bass notes and falling rain leads to precussive tinkles.  All in all the video and audo worlds collide beatifully, and is a thoroughly meditative experience.  I've not experienced anything quite like it.Ultimately though this feeling wore off rather quickly and just lead to boredom.  I wondered around for the best part of an hour and let the game reach its conclusion.  I can't deny that this was a work of art, and a lovingly crafted calming diversion.  I respect it for trying to be different, its an experimental album if you will, and the world is a better place for having things like this.  I want to love this game but however hard I try I can't bring myself to recommend it.  There's just not enough to do.  But maybe that's the point?If you are like me then a review like this will make you want to play it more just to see what its like and prove me wrong.   You won't regret it, but a few weeks down the line "Proteus" will be just another word languishing in your Steam games list.

Posted: August 10, 2014
												I began my journey not knowing what to expect. I awoke in an 8 bit world. I was about to have a first person atari style adventure. I was in the middle of what appeared to be a vast ocean. It was very foggy, but I could see land in the distance. I could also see a comforting and familiar sun. I choose to head towards land. Gameplay wise, there isn't much there. wasd to move and you can also look around. Initially I was annoyed at the slow pace and the fact that once I had arrived at a castle like building I could not enter. My curiousity to learn more drove me to continue my journey. There were interesting sounds and visions all around. I appeared to be on an island inhibited by many creatures and containing it's own weather system. Soon enough the clouds began to disperse and the sun began to set. With night upon me I enjoyed some light star gazing upon a snowy mountain top. I noted the slow movement of the stars. Once again my emotions switched when I came to a small cottage down the mountain side following a dirt path. Not only could I not enter this cottage, but the door itself looked terrible. I would not be fooled....no one lives here. No one has for some time.....I started my next day much like the first, blindy moving forward in an effort to discover what, if anything, remains to be discovered. This is where I had my first encounter. A silly creature bounced gracefully away from me. It did not matter how I decided to approach, the creature was sure to make haste. Remnicient of Stan's dad in South Park attempting to "catch the Dragon" I gave chase to this creature. I followed it so long that eventually we arrived at the shore line. Sadly the creature simply hopped into the water, never to be seen again. I happened upon numerous more of these creatures during my team on the island. My experience remained the same. I would follow until I could no longer. Eventually I found a circle of what appeared to be grave stones. Upon bumping into one I noticed a small "bend" in reality. The world in which I was located was being distorted by these things. Whilst looking around  I realized the pace of this world changing picking up. Soon I was watching as days were flying by before my eyes. Getting a grip on my bewilderment I became aware of the small circle in the center of these stones, seemingly created by wind. It seemed to call me. Feeling as though it was my destiny I entered the circle.Opening my eyes once again I took note of a slightly new sun. Perhaps this was a new world, or perhaps I had simply traveled through time. The landscape had changed. The entire pace of things seemed to pick up entirely. Wildlife was much more abundant than the when or where from which I had traveled. I had received exactly what I had asked for, as if I had somehow  directed the growth of this existence. After taking in what this new landscape had to offer I once again happened upon the bounding bouncing creature from before. Only this time something was different. The creature appeared to have let me get ever so slightly closer before making it's escape. I'm not sure what will happen to me now. I feel as though my only route is forward. It is as if I have put a curse on myself to make a goal of understanding this creature. I fear I may never catch it, but I also feel that I must try. It occurs to me that I may travel endless worlds in search of my goal, wandering through time and space relentlessy. It is for that reason that I leave this record of my travels. Perhaps as a warning, perhaps as an explanation. If this is to be my last correspondence, please hope for me. Hope that I have attained my goal of capturing the bouncing creature. ------I would definitely define this as an exploration or art type game. It is a soothing experience that may help certain people feel calm or tap into the childlike wonder of days long past many of us have forgotten. Recommended For: Anyone with a tramatic past"City-folk" who will never see real starsIndividuals afraid to leave their homesAnyone who is really stoned.Not Recommended for: Graphics ♥♥♥♥♥sFast paced action junkiesMeth addicts. Recommended, but only under specific conditions. I honestly would probably be upset if I had paid much for this game.

That's when you konw you've injected some serious marijuana. watching the faces come out of the walls, along with the 2D sprites that makes up the demon invaders, you'll turn to your wise cracking partner, the mask of death, and say "you made armor for the demon invaders. Shut the ♥♥♥♥ up!". This is only one of the many scripted sequences this horror game has. They sky is made of blue. Posted: October 28, 2015
												If you're reading reviews, well, I take it that means you're on the fence. A nice pair of headphones makes Proteus a much more immersive and awe-inducing experience. Otherwise, well, it's probably not nearly as impressive. If you have a nice pair of headphones and are still hesitant, well... I would be hesitant too, at full price. I bought this as part of a humble bundle. As much as I enjoy Proteus (and sharing this game with others, especially), 10 euro is asking a lot.Calling this a "game" isn't quite right. It's more of an exploratory experience, like Dear Esther but with more freedom and much more wow, even with the graphic downgrade. There's no story, no goal, just wandering around an island populated by things and beings that create an aural and visual landscape. The "island" changes with each playthrough, though in the games I've loaded, it's always been populated by the same beings/things. Except that one time, in the graveyard with the firefly symphony-whirlpool that controlled time. Never was able to make that happen a second time.

												It's very important to keep in mind that Proteus is not a game. It is a relaxation toy. Posted: May 17, 2014
												I had just finished a stressful match of League of Legends and I decided that I needed to take a breather, so I loaded up Steam and remembered I had just bought this game as apart of a Humble Bundle. Figuring that it could be good, I installed it, put on my headphones, and dove in. Waking up waist deep in the pixelated ocean, I was immersed in a simple yet utterly beautiful world. I watched day turn to night and night turn to day. There were no goals, nor any rules of what I had to do. I walked around an island, listening to the world. I climbed a mountain and heard the sea wind blowing. I walked into the rain and heard a gentle drizzle land on the nearby trees. As I played-- no, not played. As I experienced Proteus, I felt my muscles relieve themselves, and even now do I feel utterly calm. I can't explain this game, because it's not a game. Walking through Proteus was a reminder that the world is beautiful, and all we have to do is take time to see it.

Posted: May 17, 2016
												Proteus is basically an island you can generate with your computer. There's a full range of plants and animals, a handful of landmarks, and a couple of secrets and surprises. Although there isn't much to do in Proteus, the procedurally generated landscape, fudgy graphics, and kaleidoscopic sound occasionally come together into something worth bearing witness to. If nothing else, Proteus can be enjoyed passively and functions well as a palette cleanser.There also exists a free mod called Purgateus, which uses alternate graphics and sound to create a darker setting.

Posted: August 27, 2016
 For those who love music Personally, I enjoy this game. I absolutely love video game soundtracks, however, this soundtrack is different. Typically, video game soundtracks are something on the side. The music plays in the background or it may be a part of an event in the game. Let's use  Skyrim  and its soundtrack as an example representing most other games. The soundtrack to that game is my favorite soundtrack ever, but it isn't interactive. Songs play in certain areas and play for certain events (like battles). Proteus  is different. Everything around you is part of the sountrack you create simply by being around those objects. Everytime you play, the soundtrack changes. You won't experience the same soundscape twice. That's something I enjoy. The music is very relaxing and there aren't really any objectives. I think that's a good thing. With games like  Minecraft  (another game with a beautiful soundtrack) there aren't really any set objectives or goals. You're just there in the world and you can do whatever you'd like, but the soundtrack is just an added part of the game. It isn't integral to the game. With  Proteus,  the sounds are everything. It's basically the point of it all.Nothing is perfect, so I do have a problem with this game. There are options to play older versions of this game, which is fantastic. The problem I have is that there aren't many options to choose from. There are the versions after the full 1.0 release, and a beta...  just one. I wish there were more beta versions that I could play. There is a particular version that I wish to play (the February 2012 version) because I prefer certain cound effects in that version over the ones in the newer versions. I came to know about this game through that version and that's the  Proteus  I fell in love with.Overall, I enjoy this game. Some might not call it a game, but I certainly do. It's definitely not for everyone, though. If you like relaxing games or ambient music, then this game is a good choice.

Posted: December 11, 2014
												Number one; this is an intensely buggy game. All it did for the first few months of my owning it was crash almost immediately when it was opened. It was only through some vague whim that I happened to try and load it again ages after purchasing it.While I fear I will be accused of missing the point, I must admit to finding Proteus utterly pointless. It is less a game, than a screen-saver and must be regarded as unfinished, laziness, as opposed to avant-garde, 'higher-meaning', indie game. Not all games need a crude starting line and a goal, but they need something more than the Emeperors Clothes that this game is evidently adorned in. Proteus is a meandering and ultimately unnecessary experience for anyone to have. It's only use might be to gently ease people back into society after some horrible, drug-addled. breakdown, but it's certainly not as a videogame. When you finally exit Proteus, the pixels make for an eye-closing animation; but my real eyes had already done that long ago. It was like a trip to the shops, only with less to show for it; I could have got a pint of milk during all of that pointlessness.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												It is incorrect to say this is not a game and more like an interactive experience. Yes it is an interactive experience, all games are interactive experiences, but this is indeed a game. Those that claim it is not a game just haven’t spent the time figuring out the mechanics of the game or taken the time to search for guides online. You can choose to explore aimlessly and enjoy the peacfulness of the world or you can follow a set of rules in order to experience the timeline of the game and end (or beat) the game. Unless you create a snapshot, everytime you play the game you will be in a newly generated world. So even if you've finished the game before, you can try again in a new world.

Posted: February 2, 2015
												To the game's credit, it has very nice ambient sound/music. It adds additional little notes and melodies that play depending what you're looking at or near and what's happening, and that part is very nicely done. All in all though, I found this game a bit of a let down. The environments are too repetetive to make exploration a very rich experience for more than the first couple minutes, and the game itself is over very quickly. I finished it without feeling like I had explored much of anything, without feeling like I had felt deeply relaxed or enjoyed any beautiful scenery, without feeling like anything interesitng had been communicated to me via sublte symbolism - more or less feeling like I'd barely played a game at all. I feel like the use of audio in this game shows a lot of creativity and potential, but unfortunately there's not much else to see here. I'm afraid I've got to agree with the reviews saying you've basically played the game by watching the trailer.

Posted: August 10, 2014
												I began my journey not knowing what to expect. I awoke in an 8 bit world. I was about to have a first person atari style adventure. I was in the middle of what appeared to be a vast ocean. It was very foggy, but I could see land in the distance. I could also see a comforting and familiar sun. I choose to head towards land. Gameplay wise, there isn't much there. wasd to move and you can also look around. Initially I was annoyed at the slow pace and the fact that once I had arrived at a castle like building I could not enter. My curiousity to learn more drove me to continue my journey. There were interesting sounds and visions all around. I appeared to be on an island inhibited by many creatures and containing it's own weather system. Soon enough the clouds began to disperse and the sun began to set. With night upon me I enjoyed some light star gazing upon a snowy mountain top. I noted the slow movement of the stars. Once again my emotions switched when I came to a small cottage down the mountain side following a dirt path. Not only could I not enter this cottage, but the door itself looked terrible. I would not be fooled....no one lives here. No one has for some time.....I started my next day much like the first, blindy moving forward in an effort to discover what, if anything, remains to be discovered. This is where I had my first encounter. A silly creature bounced gracefully away from me. It did not matter how I decided to approach, the creature was sure to make haste. Remnicient of Stan's dad in South Park attempting to "catch the Dragon" I gave chase to this creature. I followed it so long that eventually we arrived at the shore line. Sadly the creature simply hopped into the water, never to be seen again. I happened upon numerous more of these creatures during my team on the island. My experience remained the same. I would follow until I could no longer. Eventually I found a circle of what appeared to be grave stones. Upon bumping into one I noticed a small "bend" in reality. The world in which I was located was being distorted by these things. Whilst looking around  I realized the pace of this world changing picking up. Soon I was watching as days were flying by before my eyes. Getting a grip on my bewilderment I became aware of the small circle in the center of these stones, seemingly created by wind. It seemed to call me. Feeling as though it was my destiny I entered the circle.Opening my eyes once again I took note of a slightly new sun. Perhaps this was a new world, or perhaps I had simply traveled through time. The landscape had changed. The entire pace of things seemed to pick up entirely. Wildlife was much more abundant than the when or where from which I had traveled. I had received exactly what I had asked for, as if I had somehow  directed the growth of this existence. After taking in what this new landscape had to offer I once again happened upon the bounding bouncing creature from before. Only this time something was different. The creature appeared to have let me get ever so slightly closer before making it's escape. I'm not sure what will happen to me now. I feel as though my only route is forward. It is as if I have put a curse on myself to make a goal of understanding this creature. I fear I may never catch it, but I also feel that I must try. It occurs to me that I may travel endless worlds in search of my goal, wandering through time and space relentlessy. It is for that reason that I leave this record of my travels. Perhaps as a warning, perhaps as an explanation. If this is to be my last correspondence, please hope for me. Hope that I have attained my goal of capturing the bouncing creature. ------I would definitely define this as an exploration or art type game. It is a soothing experience that may help certain people feel calm or tap into the childlike wonder of days long past many of us have forgotten. Recommended For: Anyone with a tramatic past"City-folk" who will never see real starsIndividuals afraid to leave their homesAnyone who is really stoned.Not Recommended for: Graphics ♥♥♥♥♥sFast paced action junkiesMeth addicts. Recommended, but only under specific conditions. I honestly would probably be upset if I had paid much for this game.

Posted: February 22, 2013
												Proteus is a interesting creation to me, It's clearly a video game but the it's nothing like I've played before, however saying that it does resemble some similarity to another game called "Dear Esther", the idea of both of those games is to explore and have a sense of adventure to progress to completing it. In Dear Esther however there is a narrator telling you bits of a story and it all pieces together when you finish the journey, in Proteus though there isn't a back story, or a plot, or an objective, there's nothing to do either,  it's very mysterious and from what I've heard from people they've seen and found thing I didn't see and vice versa.You start the game by left clicking on the isles in the background, you spawn in the ocean next to the shore, you use the WASD keys to move and mouse to look around as the norm for most PC games, you must explore to continue the game and like I said before there's no object so do as you please, also the notice how the music changes depending on where you are, but it's not only the music you should notice, everything in the environment makes a unique sound of some sort. I remember chasing a frog for a while all because it makes a sparkly spring noise when it hops, everything makes a sound, and sometimes you have to wait until night time to hear some interesting sounds. I found to continue to another part of the game, you have to wait until night time and find out where the these floating white partials are heading and follow them, you'll soon find a large cluster of them almost dancing in a circle, head inside the circle and you'll be taken into a new part of the game, it's easy to figure out what this game is basing its ideas on but all the same, you'll have to see for yourself, or buy it and have a go.Not much else to say about Proteus with it being a sort game, I managed to finish just under an hour, but if you take your time and find everything you can find this game will easily last you more than a week. I urge  everyone who reads this to please try it out, over your mind to something bigger than your attachment to your comfort zone and try something new, it's won't hurt to try right? Thank you for reading!

												This game is different. It's not about gameplay in my opinion but more about an experience. You start of-shore next to an island. You walk to that island and then what? You don't have much to do but walk. But then what made me get 95 minutes of play time? I turned up my volume on my headset and enjoy the audio. What I like about this game is that you open it and you look... You basicly look around and watch the environment around you.You can find alot of stuff in the randomly generated world. You see statues and stones and you can watch the rain fall down. Or you can find animals jumping around or flying around.It's really immersive and exciting to play through the first time.Ontop of that it's calming... You start it up on a stressful day and you relax.I recommend this game because it's cheap and it's short... That's usually not a good combination but depending on your reasoning to buy this game it can be. Personally I bought it because I needed a game I could relax with. But it's also not worth 19,99€I opened the game and played a bit and then closed it... I never got to the final "level" before today. It was truly an experience to look at how the game changes while you play. I'm glad I got this game and I will probably load it up more.

I came back to it today wandered around for a bit and then after a while I started to understand what it was about.When I came back to it this time, I didn't try and do anything, I just wandered around, and then I understood what I was supposed to do - which was just to wander around!This isn't a game about competition, its not a game with much of a story, its not a game about self-improvement, but it is Art.

Posted: July 4, 2016
												I hesitate to thumbs-up this game because not everyone will experience the same catharsis as I, and others who've reviewed this game have. Before I go further, I'll say I'm a sucker for interesting art styles and good music. The reviews on Proteus and the Summer Steam Sale convinced me it was time to give it a go. I smoked, fired up Steam, and embarked on my journey into Proteus.I was delighted with every little creature I came across. Some animals were recognizable, others were alien to me. Each creature emanated its own ethereal melody; not a single bit of negativity to be seen. The pixelated art encouraged me to use my imagination to fill in the blanks--tabula rasa, if you will. Before long, I began to feel the anxiety of having no objectives, or even a button to interact with my surroundings, creep into my psyche. But when I found a group of singing pink mushrooms that popped down into the earth at my approach, only to pop back up nearby, I was satisfied to just experience the land. It became refreshing to not have to put forth effort to have a lovely experience, like receiving a massage. As for the circle of mysterious stone statues, the gravestones littering the land, the cabin in the woods, or the mother tree at the foot of the mountain...the lore behind them was whatever I want it to be. I learned to be present in the moment.This game reminded me a bit of Flower, the game that many folks insisted was not a game, but more of a toy. But the message behind Flower is the same I received from Proteus; sit back, relax, experience, and do or don't do whatever you like.My only frustration with this game is the mouse sensitivity. Even turned all the way up, I would have to lift my mouse up off the mousepad at least 10-20 times to turn around and go back the way I came. It definitely fudged with the flow of the game and introduced frustration where there had previously been calm delight. At times, I was so annoyed that I wanted to put the game down, but wanted to see it through to the end--and there IS an end.I can see many traditional hardcore gamers getting frustrated with this game. Many might perceive it as empty, devoid of any sense of accomplishment or productivity, with the beautiful art and lilting music being small compensation for the cost. Unfortunately, I think a large majority of gamers simply won't want to find the headspace to enjoy this game to its fullest, hence my hesitation to recommend it. If you can read the reviews and know Proteus is your cup of tea, buy it, mate! If you're still cautious, wait for it to go on sale and buy it for a few bucks.

Posted: October 5, 2016
												Spoilers:I play this game whenever I want to relax and waste some time. Proteus is a very simple game where you walk around and explore. There are different scenes to the game. At the start of the game, you awaken in the sea with an island ahead of you. It is spring time. There are new born animals jumping about and exploring the land similar to what you are doing, for the first time. As the sun drops and the moon rises the stars appear and you can see an unusual cluster of stars dropping and flowing towards this one point in the game. As you follow you are engulfed by the stars and time speeds up. When you are released the scenery has changed. It is summer time. Here there are more animals and bugs. The music is upbeat and happy. You explore more of the land and follow some creatures around. Once night falls again, you are swallowed by the stars again.It is autumn. Here the trees leaves start to fall off and turn brown. There are less animals and the music is starting to slow down and become sadder. You explore more. The stars once again fall down around you.It is winter. The trees are dead. No animals are in sight. The music is merely just a humming. You explore more. Everything seems dull and depressing now. The stars don't come and get you. You wait through the night.You feel tired, depressed and cold. You raise into the sky. You close your eyes. This is the end.I feel that Proteus is a game about life. You rise in the spring and fall in the winter. The atmosphere in this game is very strong and it makes you really want to keep exploring and you wonder what has changed for each season. Great game.

												Proteus is, in my opinion, one of the prettiest games I've ever had the pleasure of exploring. While it lacks the technical power/marvel of higher-budget games, the aesthetic and atmosphere is something that higher graphical fidelity would struggle to achieve.The simple, somewhat  abstract graphics and minimalist soundscape created a surreal atmosphere that used my imagination and curiosity to draw me into the experience. Posted: May 29, 2015
												Thought I would try one  of these "artsy/poetic" games. Thought it would be interesting, but it was pretty boring.  The main screen left me a little confused on how to even start playing. Thought I had to hit the title screen but it was apparentlly the image (you can interact with pretty much everything on the main screen.) I get it is supposed to be some walk and enjoy the scenery game, but the art style just didn't do it for me. Just blocky trees and mountains and I guess things supposed be animals like baby chicks. The music in the beginning sounded like some weird alien sci-fi-esque tune, Later on it sounded okay.  Either way, felt the music choice didn't really fit the walking around.  The only slightly amusing thing I guess was the little bouncing characters(which when I followed seemed to lead me to the water?) but that's about it. There's is no set place to go, just walk around and explore the one island, where everything looks very similar but in maybe two different colours.If you like an interactive screensaver or want something soothing before you go to sleep, check it out.

Posted: May 17, 2015
												A strange, but beautiful game that does what it sets out to do. Create a vibrant atmosphere. You will have some fun with discovering the randomly generated worlds and find new things you can do. However, it is a limited experience and you should not count on spending more than 30 minutes or so in the game to get your fill for some time. Sadly, I cannot be certain you will get your money’s worth out it, as it is priced way too high compared to the experience you get.I was quite satisfied with it, but I did also use it for a study project, so my estimate of the time you can use playing it is accurate. As such, I cannot recommend it at the price, but get it on a 75% sale or so and you will definitely find some enjoyment. If nothing else, it is a very relaxing little game.

Posted: February 3, 2013
												To call Proteus a game would be selling it short. Much like Dear Esther, Proteus isn't so much a game, as it is an art piece. Unlike Dear Esther though, each viewing is different, your islands are randomly generated. The graphics and sound are all perfectly simplistic and work oh so well in tandem. The only interactions are your movements and discoveries through the beautifully pixelated world. The sound especially is the draw, changing to different soothing tones based off your surroundings and season. While it's possible to see everything in a single island, you'll want to keep coming back to view it in a different setting. If you find something that takes your breath away, you can share the postcard (F9 ingame) with friends to let them explore the same island. If you're at all interested in interactive art, Proteus is a must play.

Posted: June 15, 2013
												I just finished this game, and my first impression was more or less: "WOAH..." First things first, this is definetly not the kind of game for everyone. To be specific, a very narrow demographic would enjoy it. Theres a couple of things I felt that made it possible for me to play the whole game in one sitting (took about an hour to complete). 1. Play with friends, this game would be intolerable by yourself (maybe that's just me)2. You have to be the kind of person that is open minded, because if you're used to the status-quo when it comes to games, Proteus is not for you. Final Thoughts: If you allow it, this game will honestly change you. I gained a new respect for the beauty of nature, but more prominently, I felt like I had become a more Zen person. My patience level has skyrocketed, and I feel like I can better enjoy life and all its hidden meaning. Replay Value: There is none. I dont feel like I'll ever play again, or need to for that matter, but it was definetly fun while it lasted.Money Value: Not worth $10.

Posted: June 8, 2013
												Kind of like a 320x200 video game rendering of "Koyaanisqatsi." Not just because its primary appeal is its visuals, but also because of its pretty neat, procedurally generated, Phillip Glass-esque score. The primary mechanic is exploration and the combination of the audio and visuals make it play more like a sort of extended tone poem than a "game," but there are interactive elements and new things to see and discover on different playthroughs. Not sure if there's enough there to warrant many play throughs, but it is incredibly....relaxing. Its cumulative effect is a bit like popping a couple valium and listening to one of those self-hypnosis relaxation tapes (which wouldn't be a compliment if referring to most games, but in Proteus' case it is). In fact, it's so relaxing that I kind of find the demand to control it to be a bit of an impediment at times. Someone needs to make an "auto-wander" mod for it so I could turn it on and veg out when I'm stressed or just fall asleep to it.

Posted: December 11, 2014
												Number one; this is an intensely buggy game. All it did for the first few months of my owning it was crash almost immediately when it was opened. It was only through some vague whim that I happened to try and load it again ages after purchasing it.While I fear I will be accused of missing the point, I must admit to finding Proteus utterly pointless. It is less a game, than a screen-saver and must be regarded as unfinished, laziness, as opposed to avant-garde, 'higher-meaning', indie game. Not all games need a crude starting line and a goal, but they need something more than the Emeperors Clothes that this game is evidently adorned in. Proteus is a meandering and ultimately unnecessary experience for anyone to have. It's only use might be to gently ease people back into society after some horrible, drug-addled. breakdown, but it's certainly not as a videogame. When you finally exit Proteus, the pixels make for an eye-closing animation; but my real eyes had already done that long ago. It was like a trip to the shops, only with less to show for it; I could have got a pint of milk during all of that pointlessness.

Posted: May 17, 2016
												Proteus is basically an island you can generate with your computer. There's a full range of plants and animals, a handful of landmarks, and a couple of secrets and surprises. Although there isn't much to do in Proteus, the procedurally generated landscape, fudgy graphics, and kaleidoscopic sound occasionally come together into something worth bearing witness to. If nothing else, Proteus can be enjoyed passively and functions well as a palette cleanser.There also exists a free mod called Purgateus, which uses alternate graphics and sound to create a darker setting.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												This game's very design--from the curious yet delightful sounds, soft and pleasant colors, and soul-quelling music, to the way the player's screen enters and exits the game like eyes slowly opening and closing--is meant to be strongly reminiscent of a dream; a beautiful, subjective dream. A dream where the more you get lost within, the more you get lost within your own thoughts. Abandon the day-to-day burdens of goals, duties, tasks, competition, opposition, and reward--the values that our workaholic, robotic, and disconnected society holds so dear. Abandon those--just for a few moments, and take the time to bask yourself into consciousness within another plane. Take the time to simply... be.

Posted: December 21, 2013
												It's not really a game so much as it is an adventure. It's not meant to be played, it's meant to be explored. This game can only be fun if you take it with an open mind. Absorb the surroundings, see what things make what sounds. The point is to feel like a child exploring the forest. See something interesting? walk towards it. Found a circle of totem poles? Try and find out if they do something. Herd of pink chickens? Chase them! Sure, the graphics do take away from the experience (I think if it had mor realistic graphics I'd feel more inclined to explore), but it's an experience all the same. Also, play more than once. More things seem to appear the more you often you play.I find it to be overpriced, I reccomend if on sale.

Posted: March 23, 2013
												This game is without a doubt absolutely magical. Sure, from a technical stand point, it is not that graphically impressive, but once you're in the game, and begin to experience all the wonders this has to offer, it will quickly no longer matter. This game invokes an almost child-like sense of discovery, something I haven't felt replicated in many other, if any. The adaptive/procedural musical score is also a massive plus for this. You're immersed not only in your discoveries, but in the ambience as well. It's somewhat difficult to call this a game, as there are no objectives or end goals, but it is still absolutely lovely nonetheless. Definitely recommended.

Posted: July 5, 2016
												This game is different. It's not about gameplay in my opinion but more about an experience. You start of-shore next to an island. You walk to that island and then what? You don't have much to do but walk. But then what made me get 95 minutes of play time? I turned up my volume on my headset and enjoy the audio. What I like about this game is that you open it and you look... You basicly look around and watch the environment around you.You can find alot of stuff in the randomly generated world. You see statues and stones and you can watch the rain fall down. Or you can find animals jumping around or flying around.It's really immersive and exciting to play through the first time.Ontop of that it's calming... You start it up on a stressful day and you relax.I recommend this game because it's cheap and it's short... That's usually not a good combination but depending on your reasoning to buy this game it can be. Personally I bought it because I needed a game I could relax with. But it's also not worth 19,99€I opened the game and played a bit and then closed it... I never got to the final "level" before today. It was truly an experience to look at how the game changes while you play. I'm glad I got this game and I will probably load it up more.

Posted: August 27, 2016
 For those who love music Personally, I enjoy this game. I absolutely love video game soundtracks, however, this soundtrack is different. Typically, video game soundtracks are something on the side. The music plays in the background or it may be a part of an event in the game. Let's use  Skyrim  and its soundtrack as an example representing most other games. The soundtrack to that game is my favorite soundtrack ever, but it isn't interactive. Songs play in certain areas and play for certain events (like battles). Proteus  is different. Everything around you is part of the sountrack you create simply by being around those objects. Everytime you play, the soundtrack changes. You won't experience the same soundscape twice. That's something I enjoy. The music is very relaxing and there aren't really any objectives. I think that's a good thing. With games like  Minecraft  (another game with a beautiful soundtrack) there aren't really any set objectives or goals. You're just there in the world and you can do whatever you'd like, but the soundtrack is just an added part of the game. It isn't integral to the game. With  Proteus,  the sounds are everything. It's basically the point of it all.Nothing is perfect, so I do have a problem with this game. There are options to play older versions of this game, which is fantastic. The problem I have is that there aren't many options to choose from. There are the versions after the full 1.0 release, and a beta...  just one. I wish there were more beta versions that I could play. There is a particular version that I wish to play (the February 2012 version) because I prefer certain cound effects in that version over the ones in the newer versions. I came to know about this game through that version and that's the  Proteus  I fell in love with.Overall, I enjoy this game. Some might not call it a game, but I certainly do. It's definitely not for everyone, though. If you like relaxing games or ambient music, then this game is a good choice.

Posted: November 30, 2016
												Such lush scenery


Bright, green and fluffy 
A Screenshot of Proteus
By: anasofiapaixao




In a nice, relaxing atmosphere


A small slice of heaven 
A Screenshot of Proteus
By: anasofiapaixao




All joking aside, if you are the kind of person who enjoys exploring environments, feeling the mood, the atmosphere, the visual and sound immersion and feel moving around in pretty landscapes is its own reward, regardless of whichever brownie points a game might give you for exploring, you will find this gratifying. I just... definitely did not expect getting creeped out as often as I did, neither from the screenshots nor from the reviews. But it's very mild, even for someone like me who gets scared extremely, embarrassingly easily, and it does add to the experience.There is a lot of detail and thought put into processing things with your senses. I found it surprising how well the game manages to communicate other types of sensory input via sight and sound only; for instance, looking at directly at the sun is very uncomfortable and something you'll find yourself avoiding doing, same with messing with a swarm of bees. The transitions in sound are very subtle yet effective, and feels like part of a coherent whole.If feeling an environment isn't your thing, don't buy it. Otherwise it's worth it.
